description: ITIL Practitioner is a show (and qualification) developed for those IT managers and leaders who are seeking guidance on the implementation of an ITIL based framework and ITIL based processes. It is also directed at managers and leaders who are seeing to make improvements to their current ITIL based structure. In this show we cover topics ranging identifying areas for improvement and ensuring stakeholder engagement through to Organization Change Management; managing the “people” affected by and involved in transformational change. If you’re looking for a starting point to transformational change, then this is the show for you.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo introduce the upcoming ITIL Practitioner series. Jo explains who this series is intended for and what to expect while prepping for your ITIL Practioner exam.
episodes.title: Intro to ITIL Practitioner
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:02.940
Welcome to ITProTV.

2

[CROSSTALK]

3

4

>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.967 --> 00:00:14.153
>> Welcome to your
ITIL Practitioner series.

6
00:00:14.153 --> 00:00:16.540
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:21.290
In this episode, we'll really introduce,
well, at least Jo will, our ITIL expert,

8
00:00:21.290 --> 00:00:26.130

9

10
00:00:28.130 --> 00:00:29.880
>> I'm absolutely great,
how are you, Cherokee?

11
00:00:29.880 --> 00:00:33.040
>> I'm just glad you're here, because I
certainly can't deliver this information.

12
00:00:33.040 --> 00:00:37.150

be able to explain to us what we

13
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.842
have to look forward to in the series.

14
00:00:38.842 --> 00:00:43.947
>> Okay, well, in the ITIL Practitioner
class, the ITIL Practitioner

15

show is unlike any other ITIL
show that you have ever watched.

16
00:00:48.457 --> 00:00:51.644
It's unlike any class that
you've ever undertaken, and

17
00:00:51.644 --> 00:00:56.370
it's unlike any qualification in
terms of ITIL that you have ever sat.

18
00:00:56.370 --> 00:01:01.020
ITIL Practitioner does not fit
in with the actual life cycle

19
00:01:01.020 --> 00:01:05.580
stream of all of your other ITIL courses.

20
00:01:06.590 --> 00:01:11.790
This particular show will look
at the implementation of ITIL.

21
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:16.791
So, there is an assumption there and
that you have.

22
00:01:16.791 --> 00:01:21.549
And in fact, it's a prerequisite
you must have completed your ITIL

23
00:01:21.549 --> 00:01:26.830
foundation in order to be able to
sit the ITIL practitioner test.

24
00:01:26.830 --> 00:01:30.900
My recommendation is that you've
also completed your MALC as well.

25
00:01:30.900 --> 00:01:34.300
In that you have actually gone
through your intermediates, and

26
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:37.340
you have attained ITIL expert status.

27
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:41.480
And at that point in time,
this is when we look at ITIL practitioner.

28
00:01:41.480 --> 00:01:46.600
The practitioner certification is
designed for those consultants,

29
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:52.060
those specialists, and those managers
who are looking to implement ITIL.

30
00:01:52.060 --> 00:01:55.800
Implement either ITIL as a whole or
implement maybe one or

31

32
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:03.380
So it is designed for those experts
who understand ITIL completely.

33
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:09.480
You cannot implement unless you understand
what you're trying to implement.

34
00:02:09.480 --> 00:02:13.180
Which is why even though the prerequisite
is just at the foundation level

35
00:02:13.180 --> 00:02:14.470
certificate.

36
00:02:14.470 --> 00:02:17.970
I would recommend that you have
done other intermediates and

37
00:02:17.970 --> 00:02:22.260
even MALC before you attempt
to implement anything.

38
00:02:22.260 --> 00:02:26.180
You cannot implement anything, bearing
in mind that you have to adopt ITIL and

39
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:28.200
then adapt it to your environment.

40
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:30.212
You have to understand what
you're adopting first.

41
00:02:30.212 --> 00:02:30.770
So and as I said,

42
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:35.300
you can't implement anything unless
you have a full understanding of it.

43
00:02:35.300 --> 00:02:39.400
Now this class, this particular
course is completely different

44
00:02:39.400 --> 00:02:42.880
to any of the other ITIL
shows in its format.

45
00:02:42.880 --> 00:02:47.572
The recommendations from Axelos are for

46
00:02:47.572 --> 00:02:53.092
the ITIL practitioner
that we have around about

47
00:02:53.092 --> 00:02:58.350
a 25 to 35% tutor led study experience.

48
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:05.824
The remainder of that, between 65 and
75% is undertaken by exercises.

49
00:03:05.824 --> 00:03:10.789
And these are exercises designed
to test your ability to be able

50
00:03:10.789 --> 00:03:15.730
to implement ITIL and
implement any of the processes in ITIL.

51
00:03:15.730 --> 00:03:20.590
So, this test can actually test
you on any of these processes.

52
00:03:20.590 --> 00:03:22.602
Which is why I say, you have to know them.

53
00:03:22.602 --> 00:03:25.150
You have to know them like
the back of your hand,

54
00:03:25.150 --> 00:03:27.270
because your test is going to test you.

55
00:03:27.270 --> 00:03:28.620
It's gonna give you a scenario, and

56
00:03:28.620 --> 00:03:33.170
it's going to test you on your ability
to adapt ITIL in that scenario.

57
00:03:33.170 --> 00:03:37.200
So as I've said,
you have to be able to adapt ITIL.

58
00:03:37.200 --> 00:03:40.290
So you have to know it in
order to be able to adapt it.

59
00:03:40.290 --> 00:03:45.277
So, as far as this particular show is
concerned, with the ITIL Practitioner

60
00:03:45.277 --> 00:03:50.186
show, you're not going to find as many

61
00:03:50.186 --> 00:03:55.122

62

Because this particular show is focused
very much on your downloadable material

63

64

Now, as always,

65

66
00:04:12.482 --> 00:04:15.940
We're available for
you if you have any questions.

67
00:04:15.940 --> 00:04:21.224
And in fact, in terms of feedback for your
exercises, I would tell you that, yes,

68
00:04:21.224 --> 00:04:26.224
definitely come back to us, and we'll be
able to advice in any way that we can.

69
00:04:26.224 --> 00:04:32.167
Now and I'm gonna talk to you in a moment
about the format of the actual study and

70
00:04:32.167 --> 00:04:35.151

71

But what I would tell you is,
as I've already told you,

we have huge emphasis on the exercises and
not so

75

Now there's a temptation there,

77

is this something that if I feel

79

the problem with the people that

81

82

The ITIL practitioner test,

It's multiple choice,

216
00:12:40.150 --> 00:12:44.540
it's not complex multiple choice,
it's simple multiple choice.

217
00:12:44.540 --> 00:12:46.600
You've got one right answer, that's it.

218
00:12:46.600 --> 00:12:48.637
There's no points awarded,

219
00:12:48.637 --> 00:12:52.713
unlike in our intermediates,
where we had a point system.

220
00:12:52.713 --> 00:12:53.680
>> Partial credit or something like that?

221
00:12:53.680 --> 00:12:57.610
>> That's right, you had a point
system based on your best fit answer.

222
00:12:57.610 --> 00:13:01.040
Not on this one, you've either got
the right answer or the wrong.

223
00:13:01.040 --> 00:13:03.880
It's as simple as that,
very simple multiple choice.

224
00:13:03.880 --> 00:13:08.130
So it's very, very important that
you understand how we adapt to ITIL.

225
00:13:08.130 --> 00:13:12.300
Now, as I already mentioned, the early
prerequisite is for the ITIL foundation.

226
00:13:12.300 --> 00:13:15.500
But I would also recommend
that you get to know

227
00:13:15.500 --> 00:13:20.350
your other ITIL intermediates
before sitting a practitioner test.

228
00:13:20.350 --> 00:13:22.970
Because you simply cannot
implement something if you don't

229
00:13:22.970 --> 00:13:24.470
understand what you're implementing.

230
00:13:25.640 --> 00:13:27.820
So for now, what I'd like you to do is,

231
00:13:27.820 --> 00:13:32.840
I would like you to watch our foundation
recap and subsequent episodes.

232
00:13:32.840 --> 00:13:36.100
Our next two episodes are going
to be a recap of the foundation,

233
00:13:36.100 --> 00:13:39.018
just to give you that refresher
into all of those processes.

234
00:13:39.018 --> 00:13:46.032
And then, we'll then launch into
the ITIL practitioner body itself.

235
00:13:46.032 --> 00:13:47.656
And in these episodes,

236
00:13:47.656 --> 00:13:52.310
we'll be looking at various
techniques to actually adapt to ITIL.

237
00:13:52.310 --> 00:13:55.881
And then, of course,
towards the end of the show,

238
00:13:55.881 --> 00:13:58.552
we'll be going over a practice exam.

239
00:13:58.552 --> 00:14:03.088
And we'll be reviewing only the answers
in that practice exam, and also,

240
00:14:03.088 --> 00:14:07.632
I'll be giving you some hints and tips
on how to start with the exam as well.

241
00:14:07.632 --> 00:14:10.591
>> All right, perfect, Jo, thank you for
taking the time to explain that to us.

242
00:14:10.591 --> 00:14:11.830
Hope to see you soon.

243
00:14:11.830 --> 00:14:14.220
We've got a whole lot of
episodes headed your way.

244
00:14:14.220 --> 00:14:16.040
But for now, we'll go ahead and sign out.

245
00:14:16.040 --> 00:14:17.440
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

246
00:14:17.440 --> 00:14:18.200
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

247
00:14:18.200 --> 00:14:20.552
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

248
00:14:20.552 --> 00:14:26.510
[MUSIC]

249
00:14:26.510 --> 00:14:30.564
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee define what a service is and what it means to you. Jo breaks it down to a granular level to make sure the definition is completely understood.
episodes.title: Service Definition
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.337
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.337 --> 00:00:04.730
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:04.730 --> 00:00:05.780
California [CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:05.780 --> 00:00:08.265
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.265 --> 00:00:11.115
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:11.115 --> 00:00:14.495
>> Welcome to your
ITIL Practitioner's Theories.

7
00:00:14.495 --> 00:00:18.792
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose In this
episode we'll be talking about, well,

8
00:00:18.792 --> 00:00:19.757
what a service is.

9
00:00:19.757 --> 00:00:24.920
And with us today to help provide that
definition, is ITIL expert, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:26.420
How's it going today, Jo?

11
00:00:26.420 --> 00:00:28.640
>> Absolutely great, thank you,
Cherokee, how are you?

12
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:30.728
>> I'm doing well, thank you for asking.

13
00:00:30.728 --> 00:00:35.030
I don't think I'll be able to provide that
complete definition quite like you would.

14
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:38.504
So I'm looking forward to seeing
what you have to say about that.

15
00:00:38.504 --> 00:00:41.591
Well you know it's what I say in
absolutely all of the ISO classes okay.

16
00:00:41.591 --> 00:00:49.380
I know that everybody gets fed up with
this particular definition of a service.

17
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:50.980
And at this particular level,

18
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:55.840
certainly an ISO practitioner I do not
expect you to have to remember this.

19
00:00:55.840 --> 00:00:57.420
Sort of off by heart.

20
00:00:57.420 --> 00:01:00.343
But I don't expect you
to remember this at all.

21
00:01:00.343 --> 00:01:03.397
However, I do expect you to remember
the definition of a service.

22
00:01:03.397 --> 00:01:08.980
In other words, what it means and
how that translates to you.

23
00:01:08.980 --> 00:01:13.882
Now, if you remember,
way back in our introduction to ITIL

24
00:01:13.882 --> 00:01:17.911
practitioner and
also in our foundation recap.

25
00:01:17.911 --> 00:01:23.098
In those episodes and in fact if we
go over to our ITIL foundation shows.

26
00:01:23.098 --> 00:01:27.060
and if you go into any of
the intermediate show, and the Malt show.

27
00:01:27.060 --> 00:01:30.590
We explore the fact that
with ITIL you adopt and

28
00:01:30.590 --> 00:01:33.110
then you adapt the ITIL framework.

29
00:01:33.110 --> 00:01:35.000
So you can adopt any process.

30
00:01:35.000 --> 00:01:39.177
You can adopt any definition with ITIL but
then you adapt it to suit yourself,

31
00:01:39.177 --> 00:01:42.532
because it's just a best practice,
it's just a framework.

32
00:01:42.532 --> 00:01:45.190
You have to make it your own.

33
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:47.712
Well when we talk about adopting and
adapting,

34
00:01:47.712 --> 00:01:50.750
well that applies to the definition
of a service as well.

35
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:52.670
What do you consider to be a service?

36
00:01:53.930 --> 00:01:58.270
I'm gonna tell you that a service
is a means of delivering value by

37
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:02.010
facilitating the outcomes that customers
want to achieve without the ownership of

38
00:02:02.010 --> 00:02:03.200
specific costs and risks.

39
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:07.900
What on earth does that mean in plain and
simple English?

40
00:02:07.900 --> 00:02:12.010
We're gonna break that down because
in order for you to adapt to this.

41
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:14.880
Well, you first of all have to adopt it.

42
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:17.170
And in order to adopt it,
you have to understand it.

43
00:02:17.170 --> 00:02:20.110
And so, we're gonna break this down.

44
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:22.940
Services means it's delivering value.

45
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:25.250
You'll notice that that
was in capital letters.

46
00:02:25.250 --> 00:02:27.910
Because there's a definition of value,
quite simply, but

47
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:30.260
also we need to understand
what that really means.

48
00:02:30.260 --> 00:02:32.690
To customers, well who are our customers?

49
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:36.680
By facilitating the outcomes,
what does that mean?

50
00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:41.110
That they want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

51
00:02:42.490 --> 00:02:44.830
So let's break this down, first of all.

52
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:48.400
A service is a means of delivering value.

53
00:02:50.050 --> 00:02:57.249
We have to deliver something here in
IT that is valuable to our customers.

54
00:02:57.249 --> 00:02:58.865
It's not something that's valuable to us.

55
00:02:58.865 --> 00:03:01.000
It's something that's valuable to them.

56
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:06.990
It says there that it's the level to which
a service meets a customer expectations.

57
00:03:06.990 --> 00:03:10.444
And it can be managed of measured
by how much they're willing to pay.

58
00:03:10.444 --> 00:03:13.117
So value is, well, it's perceived.

59
00:03:13.117 --> 00:03:15.560
And we'll look at that in our next slide.

60
00:03:15.560 --> 00:03:18.050
But right at this
particular minute in time,

61
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:22.270
I want you to think of value
as something that we achieve.

62
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:24.390
It's something that they see.

63
00:03:25.410 --> 00:03:27.810
Value is very much perceived.

64
00:03:27.810 --> 00:03:29.930
But we need to deliver value.

65
00:03:29.930 --> 00:03:34.480
And we can quantify that sometimes
in maybe, an increase in sales.

66
00:03:34.480 --> 00:03:36.000
That's value.

67
00:03:36.000 --> 00:03:38.020
Decrease in customer complaints.

68
00:03:38.020 --> 00:03:38.820
That's value.

69
00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:41.320
Value's defined by the customer.

70
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:42.490
And, as we've already said,

71
00:03:42.490 --> 00:03:46.250
it's generally defined by how
much they're willing to pay.

72
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:49.015
So we call it an affordable
mix of features.

73
00:03:49.015 --> 00:03:53.785
But it's an achievement of objectives,
that's what we wanna facilitate.

74
00:03:53.785 --> 00:03:57.825
We wanna facilitate their outcomes,
that's what we mean by value.

75
00:03:57.825 --> 00:04:00.305
And value is not necessarily
where we increase profit,

76
00:04:00.305 --> 00:04:05.955
value maybe just about enhancing our
position within the marketplace.

77
00:04:05.955 --> 00:04:07.855
Or maybe a quicker time to market.

78
00:04:09.100 --> 00:04:12.500
One thing that we do know about value
is value changes all of the time.

79
00:04:12.500 --> 00:04:15.950
What does that really mean?

80
00:04:15.950 --> 00:04:19.952
Well what I value today is not necessarily
what I'm gonna value tomorrow.

81
00:04:19.952 --> 00:04:24.843
And what I value today is certainly
going to be different to what I valued

82
00:04:24.843 --> 00:04:25.918
ten years ago.

83
00:04:25.918 --> 00:04:30.896
Let's say,
I bought an iPhone ten years ago.

84
00:04:30.896 --> 00:04:35.300
That's when they first came out roughly,
thereabout.

85
00:04:36.360 --> 00:04:38.840
Now, let's look at
the definition of a service.

86
00:04:38.840 --> 00:04:42.830
And the services in means of delivering
value by facilitating outcomes.

87
00:04:42.830 --> 00:04:44.975
So what is the outcome, then,

88
00:04:44.975 --> 00:04:49.195
that we want facilitated on a cell phone,
on a mobile phone?

89
00:04:49.195 --> 00:04:52.772
>> To dial and
be able to make phone calls mobily.

90
00:04:52.772 --> 00:04:57.660
>> Right, to be able to make and
receive phone calls, yeah that's it.

91
00:04:57.660 --> 00:05:01.328
So ten years ago, I went out and
I bought an IPhone, by the way, I didn't.

92
00:05:01.328 --> 00:05:05.153
But anyway, [LAUGH] ten years ago,
I went out and I bought an iPhone,

93
00:05:05.153 --> 00:05:07.180
do I perceive value in that iPhone?

94
00:05:07.180 --> 00:05:10.500
Well, ten years ago, I did cuz otherwise,
I wouldn't have bought it, right?

95
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:11.936
So What did it do?

96
00:05:11.936 --> 00:05:13.990
Well it facilitated an outcome.

97
00:05:13.990 --> 00:05:17.730
That outcome was to send and receive,
well make and receive calls, right?

98
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:22.670
So if I gave you that iPhone right now,

99
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:26.670
that very same iPhone,
would you perceive value you in that?

100
00:05:26.670 --> 00:05:29.823
>> Jo, I just got an iPhone today, and
I don't think I could hold a candle to

101
00:05:29.823 --> 00:05:32.270
the model from ten years ago
to the one that I have today.

102
00:05:32.270 --> 00:05:34.278
So I wouldn't see that value.

103
00:05:34.278 --> 00:05:38.200
>> But yet
it facilitates exactly the same outcome.

104
00:05:38.200 --> 00:05:39.250
>> This is true.

105
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:40.730
>> So
why don't you see value in that name?

106
00:05:40.730 --> 00:05:44.139
>> I guess because it
doesn't exceed all of my, or

107
00:05:44.139 --> 00:05:47.220
at least even meet all of my expectations.

108
00:05:47.220 --> 00:05:49.690
Maybe my expectations have risen.

109
00:05:49.690 --> 00:05:55.250
So, I need the technology or the service
to, rise to my expectations as well.

110
00:05:55.250 --> 00:06:00.439
>> But are you saying then,
that now let's go back to this.

111
00:06:00.439 --> 00:06:05.010
The definition of a service, is it means
of delivering value by facilitating

112
00:06:05.010 --> 00:06:09.602
the outcome and the outcome is to make
a phone call and to receive a phone call.

113
00:06:09.602 --> 00:06:12.018
So your saying that your
outcome has change?

114
00:06:12.018 --> 00:06:12.818
>> Yeah.

115
00:06:12.818 --> 00:06:15.058
>> How?

116
00:06:15.058 --> 00:06:15.970
>> My value.

117
00:06:15.970 --> 00:06:17.207
[LAUGH].

118
00:06:17.207 --> 00:06:18.885
>> Right, that's the different.

119
00:06:18.885 --> 00:06:20.130
>> [LAUGH].
My value.

120
00:06:20.130 --> 00:06:23.943
Yeah, so
now I expect to sends you know emails and

121
00:06:23.943 --> 00:06:28.480
expect to log onto the internet,
and check my Facebook.

122
00:06:28.480 --> 00:06:30.232
>> But has the outcome changed?

123
00:06:30.232 --> 00:06:32.672
Because the outcome is still sending and
receiving or making and

124
00:06:32.672 --> 00:06:33.631
receiving a phone call.

125
00:06:33.631 --> 00:06:34.644
>> Right, we need to update that.

126
00:06:34.644 --> 00:06:35.815
>> Right, okay.

127
00:06:35.815 --> 00:06:37.482
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

128
00:06:37.482 --> 00:06:41.764
but this is very important,
because this is something that we have

129
00:06:41.764 --> 00:06:45.890
to understand when we're
defined in the service, in IT.

130
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:49.135
And this is actually why I wanna
have this discussion with you.

131
00:06:49.135 --> 00:06:53.263
Because you see, we have to understand
what the outcome is and this where we,

132
00:06:53.263 --> 00:06:54.885
it gets lost in translation.

133
00:06:54.885 --> 00:06:56.517
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it does.

134
00:06:56.517 --> 00:06:59.087
And we can talk about this now because,
let's look at this.

135
00:06:59.087 --> 00:07:05.392
I've just told you that the outcome of the
phone is to make and receive phone calls.

136
00:07:05.392 --> 00:07:05.892
>> Right.
>> Okay?

137
00:07:05.892 --> 00:07:07.430
So what I'm gonna do as a service

138
00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:10.920
provider, is I'm just gonna give you the
ability to make and receive phone calls.

139
00:07:10.920 --> 00:07:15.625
And then when I said to you has
the outcome changed over the last however

140
00:07:15.625 --> 00:07:16.515
many years.

141
00:07:16.515 --> 00:07:21.344
And you said, well, kind of and not
really because I still needed to make and

142
00:07:21.344 --> 00:07:25.206
receive phone calls, but
now I've got extra expectation.

143
00:07:25.206 --> 00:07:29.141
So does that mean, then, that,
me as a service provider,

144
00:07:29.141 --> 00:07:32.225
then do I have to change my expectations?

145
00:07:32.225 --> 00:07:35.265
Do I have to change what
I've defined as an outcome?

146
00:07:35.265 --> 00:07:40.000
Or is it your responsibility to tell me
that you've changed your expectations?

147
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:41.434
>> Good question.

148
00:07:41.434 --> 00:07:46.004
I think looking at both sides of that, I
think that the provider should be able to

149
00:07:46.004 --> 00:07:50.230
offer new improved enhancements and
let the customer know about it.

150
00:07:50.230 --> 00:07:52.305
>> Right!
But how do we know what new and

151
00:07:52.305 --> 00:07:54.272
improved enhancements you want?

152
00:07:54.272 --> 00:07:56.846
Some kind of market research surveys,

153
00:07:56.846 --> 00:08:00.590
looking at competitors' products,
things like that.

154
00:08:00.590 --> 00:08:02.860
>> I don't know,
I'm playing devil's advocate here, okay?

155
00:08:02.860 --> 00:08:05.327
>> [LAUGH] I know,
Jo is really putting me on the spot, guys.

156
00:08:05.327 --> 00:08:07.502
So we did not plan this or anything.

157
00:08:07.502 --> 00:08:08.709
I'm like, I don't know.

158
00:08:08.709 --> 00:08:10.493
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I can see,

159
00:08:10.493 --> 00:08:12.920
I can see her fumbling here, but
this is exactly what I wanted.

160
00:08:12.920 --> 00:08:16.070
No, no, I'm just mean,
I told her about this.

161
00:08:16.070 --> 00:08:18.485
>> As long as it helps you learn
that I'm all for it, that's fine.

162
00:08:18.485 --> 00:08:20.716
>> [LAUGH] It's okay,
I told her I was mean.

163
00:08:20.716 --> 00:08:23.055
I warned her this a long time ago.

164
00:08:23.055 --> 00:08:28.870
The point that we're making here
is that actually, you know what?

165
00:08:28.870 --> 00:08:32.455
There's a disconnect
between our conversation or

166
00:08:32.455 --> 00:08:36.050
between the way that we
envisage an outcome right?

167
00:08:36.050 --> 00:08:39.760
And yet,
I deliberately didn't warn her about this.

168
00:08:39.760 --> 00:08:41.590
I deliberately didn't plan this,

169
00:08:41.590 --> 00:08:43.770
because this is the exact
conversation that I want.

170
00:08:43.770 --> 00:08:47.630
Because this is the conversation that
happens in our organizations every single

171
00:08:47.630 --> 00:08:52.010
day, or rather, this is the conversation
that doesn't happen in our organization.

172
00:08:53.440 --> 00:08:54.940
I don't know what you value.

173
00:08:56.050 --> 00:09:00.500
I don't know what outcomes you want
facilitated unless you tell me.

174
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:05.130
But I'm not gonna wait for
you to come and tell me because if I do,

175
00:09:05.130 --> 00:09:07.540
then I'm behind the times.

176
00:09:07.540 --> 00:09:10.750
>> Right, I may go somewhere else and
get it by phone from someone else.

177
00:09:10.750 --> 00:09:14.536
>> Because you're expecting
me to wow you every year.

178
00:09:14.536 --> 00:09:15.182
>> Of course, Jo [LAUGH].

179
00:09:15.182 --> 00:09:20.264
>> With the latest and greatest,
and whatever that is that you want,

180
00:09:20.264 --> 00:09:24.310
you're expecting me to wow you with that.

181
00:09:24.310 --> 00:09:29.639
So as an IT service provider then, I have
got to be proactive in defining value.

182
00:09:30.970 --> 00:09:35.250
So in other words, I have almost
got to drive your value perception.

183
00:09:35.250 --> 00:09:38.689
This is not down to,
you just tell me what you value.

184
00:09:38.689 --> 00:09:43.297
I've gotta drive your value perception,
because if I come up with the latest and

185
00:09:43.297 --> 00:09:44.190
greatest toy.

186
00:09:44.190 --> 00:09:45.961
For instance, right now,

187
00:09:45.961 --> 00:09:50.680
the thing that everyone's talking
about is the cordless charging.

188
00:09:50.680 --> 00:09:54.200
If I come up with the latest and greatest
toy that does cordless charging, for

189
00:09:54.200 --> 00:09:56.140
instance, then you might be wowed by that.

190
00:09:56.140 --> 00:10:00.488
And you'll say, I definitely need this,
this is what I value.

191
00:10:00.488 --> 00:10:01.460
>> [LAUGH] Yeah?

192
00:10:01.460 --> 00:10:04.440
>> But then I can also guarantee
that in ten years' time,

193
00:10:04.440 --> 00:10:06.100
you won't value that anymore.

194
00:10:06.100 --> 00:10:07.460
Because something else will have happened.

195
00:10:09.860 --> 00:10:11.600
It's a difficulty for us.

196
00:10:11.600 --> 00:10:14.640
As service providers,
it's a huge challenge for

197
00:10:14.640 --> 00:10:17.530
us to actually get this
value perception right.

198
00:10:17.530 --> 00:10:20.110
And so,
going back to this particular slide,

00:18:11.930 --> 00:18:14.560
And sometimes they can be a challenge.

303
00:18:14.560 --> 00:18:19.140
And so we have to demonstrate that we're
able to work within those constraints.

304
00:18:19.140 --> 00:18:23.100
We have to understand in order to do this,
where the constraints come from.

305
00:18:23.100 --> 00:18:27.310
We have to understand whether they can
be influenced or not because some can't,

306
00:18:27.310 --> 00:18:28.750
as we've already mentioned.

307
00:18:28.750 --> 00:18:32.120
And we might need to use risk assessment
techniques in order to do that.

308
00:18:32.120 --> 00:18:36.020
Now we've looked at
risk assessment in CSI.

309
00:18:36.020 --> 00:18:38.900
We've also looked at risk
assessment in service strategy, and

310
00:18:38.900 --> 00:18:44.530
we've looked at risk assessment in a very
basic level in service design, as well.

311
00:18:44.530 --> 00:18:46.980
So we could take a look at
any one of those shows and

312
00:18:46.980 --> 00:18:52.750
we'll see more about risk assessment
techniques, such as management of risk.

313
00:18:52.750 --> 00:18:57.431
Now this is not a risk
[CROSSTALK] analysis show.

314
00:18:57.431 --> 00:19:00.800
Yeah, we're not going to be
doing risk analysis here.

315
00:19:00.800 --> 00:19:05.620
Just bear in mind that there are different
types of risk management, different types

316
00:19:05.620 --> 00:19:11.610
of risk analysis, that we have risk in
terms of risk to the organization and

317
00:19:11.610 --> 00:19:15.230
risk to the business of not
fulfilling their outcomes,

318
00:19:15.230 --> 00:19:17.460
they're not being able to
fulfill their outcomes.

319
00:19:17.460 --> 00:19:21.150
You can call that
business impact analysis.

320
00:19:21.150 --> 00:19:25.610
We also have risk management
in terms of us in IT and

321
00:19:25.610 --> 00:19:30.640
technological failure and
what risk that would present both to us,

322
00:19:30.640 --> 00:19:36.270
as a service provider and
also to the organization as a whole.

323
00:19:36.270 --> 00:19:40.480
Something else that we have to understand
when we are working out what our

324
00:19:40.480 --> 00:19:43.220
vision is, is we have to understand
who our stakeholders are.

325
00:19:43.220 --> 00:19:45.680
Who are the stakeholders?

326
00:19:45.680 --> 00:19:50.110
A stakeholder is defined in ITIL
as being an interested party.

327
00:19:50.110 --> 00:19:51.610
Who are our stakeholders?

328
00:19:51.610 --> 00:19:52.980
And what interests do they have?

329
00:19:54.420 --> 00:19:57.330
Anybody can be a stakeholder,
absolutely anybody, and

330
00:19:57.330 --> 00:20:00.590
you have to find out what motivates them.

331
00:20:00.590 --> 00:20:03.600
And we'll talk more about this when
we talk about organizational change

332
00:20:03.600 --> 00:20:06.670
management and
looking at techniques like JP Cotter, for

333
00:20:06.670 --> 00:20:09.770
instance, to create a sense of urgency.

334
00:20:09.770 --> 00:20:12.470
Because we're finding out
what influences these people.

335
00:20:12.470 --> 00:20:16.640
Well, what motivates them,
what influences them?

336
00:20:16.640 --> 00:20:19.570
And what influence did they have?

337
00:20:19.570 --> 00:20:24.840
We'll talk about stakeholder analysis a
little bit later, and stakeholder mapping.

338
00:20:24.840 --> 00:20:28.450
But quite frankly there are some
people that have a huge influence

339
00:20:28.450 --> 00:20:30.930
over anything that we're
trying to achieve and

340
00:20:30.930 --> 00:20:36.450
we have to make sure that they
are with us, that they're on board,

341
00:20:36.450 --> 00:20:41.560
that they are behind whatever our
improvement initiative is 100%.

342
00:20:41.560 --> 00:20:45.630
Because if they're not,
then they could actually

343
00:20:45.630 --> 00:20:49.120
undermine any improvement
initiative we're trying to achieve.

344
00:20:49.120 --> 00:20:53.000
Whether we're trying to implement
something really small like maybe just

345
00:20:53.000 --> 00:20:57.820
one small improvement initiative from the
CSI register or whether we're trying to

346
00:20:57.820 --> 00:21:00.720
implement a new service or
maybe even bring in a new process.

347
00:21:01.890 --> 00:21:05.570
All it takes is one person,
one negative person

348
00:21:05.570 --> 00:21:10.290
to undermine the motivation and
the morale of 500 people.

349
00:21:12.210 --> 00:21:15.480
So we have to understand
who our stakeholders are.

350
00:21:15.480 --> 00:21:19.310
And in order to do that, you have to
answer the question what's in it for me?

351
00:21:20.610 --> 00:21:23.310
What am I gonna get out of doing this?

352
00:21:23.310 --> 00:21:25.330
What benefit is it to me?

353
00:21:25.330 --> 00:21:29.150
If you're just bringing in bureaucracy and
let's face it that's how

354
00:21:29.150 --> 00:21:33.360
people can perceive us bringing in
a process, we're defining the process,

355
00:21:33.360 --> 00:21:36.490
we're bringing it in and we're saying
here's our new change management process.

356
00:21:36.490 --> 00:21:38.070
We'd like you to follow it.

357
00:21:38.070 --> 00:21:41.560
The question that they are going to ask
even if they don't ask it out loud is

358
00:21:41.560 --> 00:21:42.620
what's in it for me?

359
00:21:44.510 --> 00:21:46.840
Do I get any benefit out
of using this new process?

360
00:21:46.840 --> 00:21:48.380
Because if I don't, then I'm not going to.

361
00:21:48.380 --> 00:21:50.620
I'm just gonna bypass it, okay?

362
00:21:50.620 --> 00:21:53.810
So, again,
we have some items in Word here.

363
00:21:53.810 --> 00:21:59.750
In your templates, in your toolkit,
you have a copy of a stakeholder map.

364
00:21:59.750 --> 00:22:01.940
You have a stakeholder
analysis worksheet and

365
00:22:01.940 --> 00:22:05.960
you also have a stakeholder
communication plan.

366
00:22:05.960 --> 00:22:08.250
And in your downloadable material,

367
00:22:08.250 --> 00:22:14.100
you will have exercises on how
to use each of these templates.

368
00:22:14.100 --> 00:22:18.560
And also exercises that look at where
we would use each of these templates.

369
00:22:18.560 --> 00:22:21.730
Our stakeholder map,
being who are stakeholders are and

370
00:22:21.730 --> 00:22:26.640
what their priorities are, and our
stakeholder analysis worksheet being what

371
00:22:26.640 --> 00:22:32.190
we can do with these stakeholders to
influence them and where they need to be.

372
00:22:32.190 --> 00:22:34.790
And then our stakeholder
communication plan

373
00:22:34.790 --> 00:22:37.980
being how we communicate
with these stakeholders.

374
00:22:37.980 --> 00:22:39.820
How do you like to be communicated with,
Cherokee?

375
00:22:39.820 --> 00:22:40.820
>> Email.

376
00:22:40.820 --> 00:22:42.400
>> Email all the time?

377
00:22:42.400 --> 00:22:44.120
>> Text message secondary.

378
00:22:44.120 --> 00:22:45.630
>> Text message secondary.

379
00:22:45.630 --> 00:22:46.470
>> I hate the telephone, Jo.

380
00:22:46.470 --> 00:22:48.370
I know we were talking about that earlier,
but

381
00:22:48.370 --> 00:22:51.020
that's not my number one
way to be contacted.

382
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:53.320
>> So
face-to-face then doesn't work for you?

383
00:22:53.320 --> 00:22:55.230
>> Of course.
I didn't even think about that.

384
00:22:55.230 --> 00:22:56.440
Of course, that's my favorite, yes.

385
00:22:56.440 --> 00:22:59.970
That's probably why I don't like other
forms of, and don't like on the phone and

386
00:22:59.970 --> 00:23:02.420
I don't like through social media.

387
00:23:02.420 --> 00:23:03.870
Cuz we gotta have this, too.

388
00:23:03.870 --> 00:23:04.620
>> Right.

389
00:23:04.620 --> 00:23:05.220
Yeah.

390
00:23:05.220 --> 00:23:07.800
And you see, different people
respond better to different types of

391
00:23:07.800 --> 00:23:09.000
communication.

392
00:23:09.000 --> 00:23:11.870
And we'll always tell you that you
should always follow up with an email or

393
00:23:11.870 --> 00:23:14.020
follow up with something
that's in writing.

394
00:23:14.020 --> 00:23:17.320
But nevertheless,
we should communicate face to face.

395
00:23:17.320 --> 00:23:22.218
And this is why, think about IT people.

396
00:23:22.218 --> 00:23:28.640
They don't respond too well to being
sat in a classroom and being talked at.

397
00:23:28.640 --> 00:23:31.239
>> Especially when you're shaking
your finger and, you know.

398
00:23:31.239 --> 00:23:31.853
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

399
00:23:31.853 --> 00:23:33.590
IT people like to-
>> Anyways, right?

400
00:23:33.590 --> 00:23:36.470
>> Well,
IT people like to learn by doing things.

401
00:23:36.470 --> 00:23:38.030
>> Okay, let's try this.

402
00:23:38.030 --> 00:23:40.600
>> I am the sort of person that I
never read an instruction manual.

403
00:23:40.600 --> 00:23:41.860
I don't know about you?

404
00:23:41.860 --> 00:23:43.798
I don't think I've ever
read one in my life.

405
00:23:43.798 --> 00:23:44.760
>> Just wing it.

406
00:23:44.760 --> 00:23:47.690
>> Yeah, exactly [LAUGH] let's
figure it out for ourselves.

407
00:23:47.690 --> 00:23:49.549
And this is how IT people learn.

408
00:23:49.549 --> 00:23:51.050
We need to understand that,

409
00:23:51.050 --> 00:23:55.363
we need to understand who our stakeholders
are if we need any project to be a success

410
00:23:55.363 --> 00:23:58.505
Then we need to understand how
to communicate with people.

411
00:23:58.505 --> 00:24:02.290
Sometimes people will want snapshots.

412
00:24:02.290 --> 00:24:04.598
Sometimes people will
just want bullet points.

413
00:24:04.598 --> 00:24:08.433
In the ITIL books when we
first released version,

414
00:24:08.433 --> 00:24:13.912
the version three in 2007 at the ITIL
books I was asked by somebody,

415
00:24:13.912 --> 00:24:17.400
why we had a lot of bullet
points in the books.

416
00:24:17.400 --> 00:24:21.254
And I said well, we quite like bullet
points because they're clear concise and

417
00:24:21.254 --> 00:24:22.676
unambiguous-
>> Short, to the point?

418
00:24:22.676 --> 00:24:26.598
>> Yeah, it's all about communication,
and this person said to me well,

419
00:24:26.598 --> 00:24:31.150
I don't like bullet points, I like to
read paragraphs, and I thought, okay.

420
00:24:31.150 --> 00:24:32.845
>> You and five other people like you.

421
00:24:32.845 --> 00:24:38.160
>> [LAUGH] The fact of the matter is,
though, you see there's one person there.

422
00:24:38.160 --> 00:24:39.830
And that one person, and it just so

423
00:24:39.830 --> 00:24:44.800
happened that I was doing some
consultancy work at the time.

424
00:24:44.800 --> 00:24:49.535
And I actually had probably about 50
people in that room at that point in time.

425
00:24:49.535 --> 00:24:52.119
And you see that one person that spoke up
and said, well I don't like paragraphs,

426
00:24:52.119 --> 00:24:54.372
and so I'm not going to read it-
>> Were they the CEO?

427
00:24:54.372 --> 00:24:56.235
>> No,they weren't, [LAUGH] luckily.

428
00:24:56.235 --> 00:24:59.075
>> [LAUGH]
>> But that one person undermined

429
00:24:59.075 --> 00:25:02.495
the thoughts and the feelings
of everybody else in that room.

430
00:25:02.495 --> 00:25:05.285
Because then we polarized
everybody in that room.

431
00:25:05.285 --> 00:25:08.035
Because you had some of that
room that was sitting there

432
00:25:08.035 --> 00:25:10.940
literally saying to themselves,
what on earth is he going on about?

433
00:25:10.940 --> 00:25:12.655
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then you had other people

434
00:25:12.655 --> 00:25:15.530
in that room who were going,
actually, he's got a point.

435
00:25:16.980 --> 00:25:21.600
Completely polarized the room just by
one particular point that he made.

436
00:25:21.600 --> 00:25:28.000
And this is why I say it takes just
one person with a negative attitude

437
00:25:28.000 --> 00:25:34.140
to actually undermine 500 other people and
it can be one person,

438
00:25:34.140 --> 00:25:39.060
that one negative voice that can undermine
the success of an entire project.

439
00:25:39.060 --> 00:25:42.850
This is why it's very, very important that
we work out who our stakeholders are and

440
00:25:42.850 --> 00:25:46.000
we know what motivates them,
we know how we can influence them.

441
00:25:46.000 --> 00:25:50.270
And then we can work out exactly
what influence they have as well,

442
00:25:50.270 --> 00:25:53.610
cuz you asked a very,
very important point.

443
00:25:53.610 --> 00:25:56.510
And that important was, was he the CEO?

444
00:25:57.510 --> 00:26:00.270
In other words, you just asked
me what influence did he have?

445
00:26:00.270 --> 00:26:01.320
>> Sure.

446
00:26:01.320 --> 00:26:02.990
>> Right, and so that,
again, is really important.

447
00:26:02.990 --> 00:26:06.169
Because if you've got the CEO who doesn't
see the benefit in an improvement project.

448
00:26:06.169 --> 00:26:08.004
>> Versus Cherokee, sitting over there.

449
00:26:08.004 --> 00:26:09.415
[LAUGH]
>> Well, [LAUGH],

450
00:26:09.415 --> 00:26:12.040
no I didn't wanna say that.

451
00:26:12.040 --> 00:26:15.880
But if you've got one person who really,
really is influential.

452
00:26:15.880 --> 00:26:19.780
But doesn't want to get on board with
any project, whatever it may be,

453
00:26:19.780 --> 00:26:21.835
then that project is destined to failure.

454
00:26:22.910 --> 00:26:24.090
Simple as that.

455
00:26:24.090 --> 00:26:28.020
So we're gonna tell you then,
we're gonna look at in your exercises,

456
00:26:28.020 --> 00:26:29.050
your downloadable material.

457
00:26:29.050 --> 00:26:32.360
We're gonna tell you that you need to
use a stakeholder map at the start of

458
00:26:32.360 --> 00:26:36.450
a project when we're thinking about
what our vision is that you need to use

459
00:26:36.450 --> 00:26:41.010
a stakeholder analysis worksheet and the
stakeholder communication planner as well.

460
00:26:41.010 --> 00:26:44.700
And what we want you to do is prioritize
your stakeholders in terms of their

461
00:26:44.700 --> 00:26:49.750
interest and in terms of their influence
or their power as it is there.

462
00:26:49.750 --> 00:26:51.670
Those that have got high interest and

463
00:26:51.670 --> 00:26:55.580
are very influential then you
need to manage those closely.

464
00:26:55.580 --> 00:26:57.370
Because they're gonna well,

465
00:26:57.370 --> 00:27:00.560
if we don't keep them happy they're
gonna undermine the project.

466
00:27:00.560 --> 00:27:02.170
But those that have got low interest and

467
00:27:02.170 --> 00:27:07.010
low power, just keep an eye on them
because they could be, being quite sneaky.

468
00:27:08.050 --> 00:27:09.490
So be very, very careful.

469
00:27:09.490 --> 00:27:15.422
Prioritize your stakeholders and
then understand what influence they have.

470
00:27:15.422 --> 00:27:18.830
And always answer the question,
what's in it for them?

471
00:27:18.830 --> 00:27:21.240
Because if you can't
answer that question for

472
00:27:21.240 --> 00:27:25.320
them then they are going to be a negative
influence on any improvement project.

473
00:27:26.380 --> 00:27:30.870
And then, of course, one particular
type of stakeholder is a sponsor, and

474
00:27:30.870 --> 00:27:37.880
a sponsor is the guiding force
behind your vision for your project.

475
00:27:37.880 --> 00:27:43.770
A sponsor is somebody who literally
has influence over their project and

476
00:27:43.770 --> 00:27:45.560
who drives that project?

477
00:27:45.560 --> 00:27:50.250
So your call center managers,
your steering group members,

478
00:27:50.250 --> 00:27:52.270
your CIO, their sponsors.

479
00:27:52.270 --> 00:27:53.940
You see the examples there,

480
00:27:53.940 --> 00:27:57.020
business leaders and
senior management and advocates.

481
00:27:57.020 --> 00:28:01.390
But there are people that are in
a position to authorize and reject, and

482
00:28:01.390 --> 00:28:03.890
there are people that are in
a position to influence.

483
00:28:03.890 --> 00:28:08.040
So again, very similar to stakeholders,
a lot of this is more specific.

484
00:28:08.040 --> 00:28:11.610
We need to use a sponsor diagram and
a roadmap.

485
00:28:11.610 --> 00:28:15.830
And again, there's an example of them
with the new downloadable material, and

486
00:28:15.830 --> 00:28:21.010
also there is an exercise to do with
using Sponsor Diagrams and Roadmaps.

487
00:28:22.650 --> 00:28:25.950
So what should come out,
then, of our vision step?

488
00:28:25.950 --> 00:28:30.600
And, already, we just covered
on step in our CSI approach.

489
00:28:30.600 --> 00:28:32.910
And this is what should come out of it.

490
00:28:32.910 --> 00:28:37.010
We should understand [INAUDIBLE]
the inputs into the vision step,

491
00:28:37.010 --> 00:28:41.970
which we already covered in service
strategy and we covered in CSI as well.

492
00:28:41.970 --> 00:28:47.340
Then this is the outcomes from our
vision step in our CSI approach.

493
00:28:47.340 --> 00:28:50.710
The outcomes are a completed
Orientation Worksheet.

494
00:28:50.710 --> 00:28:52.647
The Sponsorship Roadmap.

495
00:28:52.647 --> 00:28:55.720
The Stakeholder Analysis Worksheet.

496
00:28:55.720 --> 00:29:00.046
And if you need to know anything
more about setting specific targets,

497
00:29:00.046 --> 00:29:04.661
then I want you to see your vision to
a matrix tree that we're going to look at

498
00:29:04.661 --> 00:29:06.592
when we look at measurements.

499
00:29:06.592 --> 00:29:08.751
And again we covered that in our CSI and

500
00:29:08.751 --> 00:29:11.857
we've also covered that in
service design as well, so

501
00:29:11.857 --> 00:29:16.530
please take a look at those other shows if
you need further clarification of that.

502
00:29:17.760 --> 00:29:21.470
So for this particular episode then
we've just taken a first initial look at

503
00:29:21.470 --> 00:29:23.270
the CSI approach.

504
00:29:23.270 --> 00:29:26.010
And I've highlighted some things in red

505
00:29:26.010 --> 00:29:29.870
that I need you to refer to in
your downloadable material.

506
00:29:29.870 --> 00:29:33.420
At this point in time we're going to

507
00:29:33.420 --> 00:29:38.340
say that that's it folks for
episode one, come back again.

508
00:29:38.340 --> 00:29:39.578
>> Part two?
>> Yeah, we do have a part two.

509
00:29:39.578 --> 00:29:40.281
>> Cool.

510
00:29:40.281 --> 00:29:42.811
>> On the CSI approach, and
at the end of part two,

511
00:29:42.811 --> 00:29:44.940
then you have some exercises to do.

512
00:29:44.940 --> 00:29:48.060
>> Always looking forward to those,
jumping jacks, sit ups, push ups,

513
00:29:48.060 --> 00:29:48.641
you know it.

514
00:29:48.641 --> 00:29:49.199
>> Yeah.

515
00:29:49.199 --> 00:29:50.810
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No, but thank you for

516
00:29:50.810 --> 00:29:52.690
providing that new approach, Jo.

517
00:29:52.690 --> 00:29:55.730
But we also have additional
information to cover, so ladies and

518
00:29:55.730 --> 00:29:57.180
gentlemen, stay tuned.

519
00:29:57.180 --> 00:29:59.003
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

520
00:29:59.003 --> 00:30:00.770
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

521
00:30:00.770 --> 00:30:01.620
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

522
00:30:01.620 --> 00:30:03.803
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

523
00:30:03.803 --> 00:30:09.682
[MUSIC]

524
00:30:09.682 --> 00:30:12.860
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

469
00:25:27.730 --> 00:25:29.629
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

470
00:25:29.629 --> 00:25:36.091
[MUSIC]

471
00:25:36.091 --> 00:25:38.616
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee cover Continual Service Improvement Principles. They define principles that should be applied to every improvement and every implementation initiative.
episodes.title: CSI Guiding Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.490
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:01.490 --> 00:00:04.255
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]
>> Coming at you live from

3
00:00:04.255 --> 00:00:05.685
San Francisco California.

4
00:00:05.685 --> 00:00:06.706
[CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.706 --> 00:00:08.322
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.322 --> 00:00:11.892
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:11.892 --> 00:00:14.835
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to you ITIL Practitioner series,

8
00:00:14.835 --> 00:00:17.360
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:21.490
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at CSI guiding principles.

10
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:25.430
And well, to guide us through this
episode, we have ITIL expert, Mrs.

11
00:00:25.430 --> 00:00:26.140
Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:26.140 --> 00:00:27.430
How's it going today, Jo?

13
00:00:27.430 --> 00:00:29.430
>> Absolutely great Cherokee, how are you?

14
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:30.830
>> I'm doing lovely.

15
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.390
I'm staying indoors preparing for
our solar eclipse today.

16
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:37.885
I don't know about you, but
I'll be spending my day with you, Jo.

17
00:00:37.885 --> 00:00:40.416
Well, I've already survived
one in England, so

18
00:00:40.416 --> 00:00:43.504
another one isn't really gonna
make that much difference.

19
00:00:43.504 --> 00:00:44.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I was going blind,

20
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:45.740
it's because I'm old.

21
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:47.605
It's got nothing to do
with watching the sun.

22
00:00:47.605 --> 00:00:49.500
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

23
00:00:49.500 --> 00:00:53.150
we'll go ahead and just take our
chances here and stick with ITIL.

24
00:00:53.150 --> 00:00:54.390
We know that that's a tried and

25
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:57.700
true methodology, and
that's what I'm counting on today.

26
00:00:57.700 --> 00:01:00.540
So what will we be looking
at within this episode, Jo?

27
00:01:00.540 --> 00:01:03.302
>> So you're telling me that this is
your escape from the solar eclipse?

28
00:01:03.302 --> 00:01:04.409
>> That's right.
>> That's what you're telling me right?

29
00:01:04.409 --> 00:01:05.571
>> [LAUGH] Saved by ITIL.

30
00:01:05.571 --> 00:01:06.427
>> Okay, fair enough.

31
00:01:06.427 --> 00:01:08.466
[LAUGH] Saved by ITIL.

32
00:01:08.466 --> 00:01:10.992
Okay, you're not the first person to
say that, so I'm all right with that.

33
00:01:10.992 --> 00:01:14.117
[LAUGH] CSI guiding principles.

34
00:01:14.117 --> 00:01:17.687
A lot of stuff in ITIL is
really just about common sense.

35
00:01:17.687 --> 00:01:18.199
>> Right.

36
00:01:18.199 --> 00:01:20.590
>> And
people will tell me this all the time.

37
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:22.670
They'll say yes, but
this just all makes sense.

38
00:01:22.670 --> 00:01:24.290
And that's exactly what ITIL is.

39
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:26.287
Think about where ITL came from.

40
00:01:26.287 --> 00:01:29.410
We sent out a group of academics
into the big wide world.

41
00:01:29.410 --> 00:01:35.300
And they came back with
a set of best practices,

42
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:36.730
what works and what didn't work.

43
00:01:36.730 --> 00:01:43.440
And they articulated it, and they
articulated it by way of the ITIL library.

44
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:46.990
And so this, to be perfectly honest,
is just no more than common sense.

45
00:01:46.990 --> 00:01:48.424
And that's what we're gonna do,

46
00:01:48.424 --> 00:01:50.707
is we're just gonna articulate
common sense in this.

47
00:01:50.707 --> 00:01:55.590
And our CSI guiding principles
are very much focused on the common

48
00:01:55.590 --> 00:01:58.175
sense aspect of implementation.

49
00:01:58.175 --> 00:02:00.940
And whether that's
an implementation of a service,

50
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:03.593
whether it's an implementation
of a new process.

51
00:02:03.593 --> 00:02:06.063
Whether it's a implementation or

52
00:02:06.063 --> 00:02:11.609
reorganization of a particularly
hierarchical structure, for instance.

53
00:02:11.609 --> 00:02:12.980
Just makes common sense.

54
00:02:12.980 --> 00:02:14.889
Take a look at what they are right now.

55
00:02:14.889 --> 00:02:19.093
We talk about things like keeping
it simple, and being transparent,

56
00:02:19.093 --> 00:02:21.130
and observing directly.

57
00:02:21.130 --> 00:02:22.990
And yeah, it's just common sense.

58
00:02:24.175 --> 00:02:25.355
>> All right, so number one.

59
00:02:25.355 --> 00:02:27.071
I know we've talked
about value quite a bit,

60
00:02:27.071 --> 00:02:29.071
we're taking a look here
at focusing on that value.

61
00:02:29.071 --> 00:02:31.455
We kinda wanna say,
like you said, common sense,

62
00:02:31.455 --> 00:02:34.195
stay focused on what our goal is here,
right?

63
00:02:34.195 --> 00:02:36.915
>> Exactly, so
let's take a look at focus on value then.

64
00:02:36.915 --> 00:02:41.016
So, we've aready gone into great
lengths in a lot of the other episodes,

65
00:02:41.016 --> 00:02:43.278
a lot of the other shows as well on value.

66
00:02:43.278 --> 00:02:47.726
And in fact if we look at the episodes
where we looked at the definition of

67
00:02:47.726 --> 00:02:51.845
a service, we talked about value,
as you say, at great length.

68
00:02:51.845 --> 00:02:56.230
[LAUGH] And so I'm not going to
go into this in any more detail,

69
00:02:56.230 --> 00:02:59.510
other than the fact that when
you are implementing anything,

70
00:02:59.510 --> 00:03:02.620
no matter what it is, whether it's a new
process, whether it's a new service,

71
00:03:02.620 --> 00:03:06.850
whether it's rearranging your
organizational chart itself.

72
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:10.551
You've got to think about
what the customer wants,

73
00:03:10.551 --> 00:03:11.910
think about what they value.

74
00:03:11.910 --> 00:03:16.410
Think about the, well, it says
they're an affordable mix of features.

75
00:03:16.410 --> 00:03:20.780
People always want to perceive that
they're getting value for money,

76
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:25.900
they always want to ensure that
they're not wasting money.

77
00:03:25.900 --> 00:03:29.079
Now, obviously, there are gonna be things,

78
00:03:29.079 --> 00:03:33.574
there are gonna be times when
certain sort of audits come around.

79
00:03:33.574 --> 00:03:36.387
When it's tax season, for instance,

80
00:03:36.387 --> 00:03:40.230
when you have regulations
that you have to adhere to.

81
00:03:41.335 --> 00:03:44.140
You're gonna have to adhere to those,
and sometimes they cost money.

82
00:03:44.140 --> 00:03:47.200
And we have to implement the services,
the systems.

83
00:03:47.200 --> 00:03:50.327
We have to implement processes that
are gonna help us to achieve those as

84
00:03:50.327 --> 00:03:51.860
an organization.

85
00:03:51.860 --> 00:03:55.903
And sometimes, people don't necessary
perceive value for money in that,

86
00:03:55.903 --> 00:03:58.570
they think of that as
a necessary evil sometimes.

87
00:03:58.570 --> 00:04:01.800
That's the, but we've got to do this.

88
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:04.109
But nevertheless,
it's still valuable to the organization.

89
00:04:04.109 --> 00:04:06.210
It's still value to the business.

90
00:04:06.210 --> 00:04:10.070
We have to think about both utility and
warranty.

91
00:04:10.070 --> 00:04:14.857
We have to think about the fact it's not
just doing what we're supposed to do,

92
00:04:14.857 --> 00:04:17.410
but it's how we do it as well.

93
00:04:17.410 --> 00:04:20.764
So, if we're talking about
value from money, we've gotta

94
00:04:20.764 --> 00:04:24.860
bring in the difference between
a customer and a user, for a start.

95
00:04:24.860 --> 00:04:26.900
Think about that service definition again,

96
00:04:26.900 --> 00:04:31.700
go back to one of those episodes,
you see what a customer values is.

97
00:04:31.700 --> 00:04:35.022
Well, they just want to
get what they paid for.

98
00:04:35.022 --> 00:04:39.098
But what are user values is generally
something completely different,

99
00:04:39.098 --> 00:04:43.840
which is that warranty, which is
about the usability of any service.

100
00:04:43.840 --> 00:04:47.690
So think about both,
they both have to be incorporated.

101
00:04:47.690 --> 00:04:51.260
Also, remember the value
diminishes over time.

102
00:04:52.670 --> 00:04:55.670
Let me go back to
the definition of a service.

103
00:04:55.670 --> 00:05:00.480
A service is a means of delivering value,
by facilitating outcomes

104
00:05:00.480 --> 00:05:04.980
that customers want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

105
00:05:04.980 --> 00:05:09.940
So it's a means of delivering
value by facilitating an outcome.

106
00:05:11.708 --> 00:05:16.050
So the outcome that we wanna facilitate,
then, when we buy a new cellphone,

107
00:05:16.050 --> 00:05:20.390
is we want to make a phone call and
receive a phone call, right?

108
00:05:20.390 --> 00:05:20.890
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

109
00:05:20.890 --> 00:05:21.722
>> We talked about this and yeah.

110
00:05:21.722 --> 00:05:23.046
>> Right.

111
00:05:23.046 --> 00:05:24.816
Well if I gave you, then,

112
00:05:24.816 --> 00:05:28.337
a cell phone from ten years ago,
>> [LAUGH]

113
00:05:28.337 --> 00:05:30.368
>> How much value would you perceived

114
00:05:30.368 --> 00:05:31.639
in that cellphone?

115
00:05:31.639 --> 00:05:34.331
>> Geez, it depends, we were just
talking about this the other day.

116
00:05:34.331 --> 00:05:38.669
Especially it feels like, I don't even
know, a palm pilot with the stylus and

117
00:05:38.669 --> 00:05:40.060
hopefully it will work.

118
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:43.693
Hopefully I can dial that phone number,
but yeah by today's standards,

119
00:05:43.693 --> 00:05:45.582
I'm not gonna be satisfied, sorry.

120
00:05:45.582 --> 00:05:48.827
>> No, but then it still
facilitates that same outcome.

121
00:05:48.827 --> 00:05:49.860
>> Exactly.

122
00:05:49.860 --> 00:05:54.430
>> Right, so we have to bear in mind
the value does diminish over time.

123
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:58.058
It says that it changes over time, but
let's face it, let's be honest about this.

124
00:05:58.058 --> 00:06:01.080
Value diminishes over time.

125
00:06:01.080 --> 00:06:05.610
Even though something from ten years ago
will still facilitate the same outcome,

126
00:06:05.610 --> 00:06:08.180
it doesn't mean that
it's going to be valued.

127
00:06:08.180 --> 00:06:13.150
So when we talk about focus on value, just
remember that life is going to change.

128
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:14.943
See, this sounds like
a philosophy lesson now.

129
00:06:14.943 --> 00:06:20.075
[LAUGH] But we concentrate a lot in
IT on keeping everything all up and

130
00:06:20.075 --> 00:06:25.217
running, and we forget about
the fact that things need to change.

131
00:06:25.217 --> 00:06:29.340
Especially ITIL came from the government,
originally.

132
00:06:29.340 --> 00:06:32.820
And you know what, in government circles,
in military circles,

133
00:06:32.820 --> 00:06:38.090
anywhere that's public sector, we don't
like to change cuz that involves money.

134
00:06:38.090 --> 00:06:41.880
It also involves potential
impact on stability.

135
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:44.250
And so
we don't necessarily want to change.

136
00:06:44.250 --> 00:06:46.720
But we have to,
we have to change over time.

137
00:06:46.720 --> 00:06:49.910
Because when people are coming into
the office and are sitting down, and

138
00:06:49.910 --> 00:06:52.171
I'm talking about your customers and
your users.

139
00:06:52.171 --> 00:06:54.961
When they're coming in and
they're sitting down, and they're

140
00:06:54.961 --> 00:06:58.171
looking at their screen and saying,
well, I can do more than this at home.

141
00:06:58.171 --> 00:07:00.800
That's the time when you
need to be changing.

142
00:07:00.800 --> 00:07:04.420
Business relationship management as
a process, now we found that it's service

143
00:07:04.420 --> 00:07:07.270
strategy, that's going to
have a lot to do with this.

144
00:07:07.270 --> 00:07:10.377
That's gonna influence
you in value perception,

145
00:07:10.377 --> 00:07:13.060
and in actually being
able to define value.

146
00:07:14.840 --> 00:07:18.220
So then we talk about our next
principle is designing, for experience,

147
00:07:18.220 --> 00:07:22.020
that CX, or the moments of truth,
as we call it.

148
00:07:23.110 --> 00:07:28.580
Every single interaction with IT
is what we call a moment of truth.

149
00:07:28.580 --> 00:07:31.363
So Cherokee,
I'm gonna ask you a question now.

150
00:07:31.363 --> 00:07:32.021
>> Okay.

151
00:07:32.021 --> 00:07:35.129
>> [LAUGH] I'm deliberately
gonna trip her up.

152
00:07:35.129 --> 00:07:36.409
[LAUGH] All right.

153
00:07:36.409 --> 00:07:37.350
Because I like being me.

154
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:39.810
>> It's okay.
It's like other everyday thing here.

155
00:07:39.810 --> 00:07:40.950
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

156
00:07:40.950 --> 00:07:43.370
how do you send an email Cherokee?

157
00:07:43.370 --> 00:07:44.650
>> All right, Jo.

158
00:07:44.650 --> 00:07:47.520
So I'm gonna have a better answer
than the one I've given before.

159
00:07:47.520 --> 00:07:52.372
But with my computer,
I am going to log in.

160
00:07:52.372 --> 00:07:57.313
I am going to connect to my network,
I'm gonna utilize network protocols

161
00:07:57.313 --> 00:08:02.354
to go ahead and send that transmission,
and Hit Enter, Send, whatever.

162
00:08:02.354 --> 00:08:04.641
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, really,

163
00:08:04.641 --> 00:08:06.810
did you understand any of that?

164
00:08:06.810 --> 00:08:09.361
Seriously, did you understand any of that?

165
00:08:09.361 --> 00:08:11.930
What she actually meant was hey,

166
00:08:11.930 --> 00:08:16.464
she's gonna plug in her computer,
she's gonna open it.

167
00:08:16.464 --> 00:08:19.013
>> [LAUGH]
>> Then she's gonna log in and

168
00:08:19.013 --> 00:08:23.420
she's gonna press Enter when she logs in,
and these gonna connect to the network.

169
00:08:23.420 --> 00:08:25.897
She don't need to know anything
about network protocols,

170
00:08:25.897 --> 00:08:27.441
it's gonna connect to the network.

171
00:08:27.441 --> 00:08:30.767
And then she's going to click on
that little icon icon that says

172
00:08:30.767 --> 00:08:31.905
Microsoft Outlook.

173
00:08:31.905 --> 00:08:36.587
And then that's going to come up, and then
at that point in time, she's going to look

174
00:08:36.587 --> 00:08:40.768
for and identify the icon that says new
email and she's gonna click on that.

175
00:08:40.768 --> 00:08:43.246
Then she's going to add
a name into the To field and

176
00:08:43.246 --> 00:08:46.408
then she's gonna type something
into the subject field.

177
00:08:46.408 --> 00:08:49.891
Then she's gonna type
the body of her email and

178
00:08:49.891 --> 00:08:55.268
she might actually attached a document and
then she's gonna hit Send.

179
00:08:55.268 --> 00:09:00.100
See the difference in what I said
compare to what Cherokee said?

180
00:09:00.100 --> 00:09:03.295
Cuz Cherokee is looking at this
from a technical perspective.

181
00:09:03.295 --> 00:09:06.331
Cherokee is looking at this
from the IT perspective.

182
00:09:06.331 --> 00:09:08.990
We're delivering value to customers and
end users.

183
00:09:08.990 --> 00:09:10.070
And to be perfectly honest,

184
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:12.411
we don't care about what happens
in the background, right?

185
00:09:12.411 --> 00:09:16.310
We're interested in the moments of
truth from the customer perspective.

186
00:09:16.310 --> 00:09:21.398
And from the customer perspective,
we need to identify

187
00:09:21.398 --> 00:09:26.930
exactly what they're interactions
are with the computer.

188
00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:28.830
Because we have to design for

189
00:09:28.830 --> 00:09:32.800
those interactions and
make them as painless as possible.

190
00:09:34.430 --> 00:09:37.247
I have a Mac, and sometimes,

191
00:09:37.247 --> 00:09:42.207
when I'm trying to attach
maybe a photo to an email,

192
00:09:42.207 --> 00:09:46.291
it's not quite as easy as you might think.

193
00:09:46.291 --> 00:09:48.960
Cuz sometimes you are able to drag and
drop, and

194
00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:51.510
sometimes you're not able to drag and
drop.

195
00:09:52.790 --> 00:09:54.891
What relevance does that
have on all of this?

196
00:09:54.891 --> 00:09:57.151
Well, because we're designing for
experience and

197
00:09:57.151 --> 00:10:00.450
we're implementing an improvement and
here we are in ITIL practitioner.

198
00:10:00.450 --> 00:10:04.291
And so if we're designing for experience
I need to know what doesn't work and

199
00:10:04.291 --> 00:10:06.255
I need to know what the pain points are.

200
00:10:06.255 --> 00:10:10.482
And I need to know the points in time when
my customer is gonna be sitting there

201
00:10:10.482 --> 00:10:13.956
with their screens going for
heavens sake this needs to work.

202
00:10:13.956 --> 00:10:15.710
>> [LAUGH]
>> Why won't this work?

203
00:10:17.480 --> 00:10:22.978
So I need to be able to identify those
moments of truth as we call them.

204
00:10:22.978 --> 00:10:28.072
The interactions, the customer
experience because when I'm implementing

205
00:10:28.072 --> 00:10:33.005
an improvement, the bits those periods
in time when I'm standing there,

206
00:10:33.005 --> 00:10:37.590
screaming at my PC,
that's what IT have got to design for.

207
00:10:37.590 --> 00:10:40.126
I don't care what network protocol we use.

208
00:10:40.126 --> 00:10:42.290
That's down to our
techie guys to sort out.

209
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:47.059
They're gonna sort this out, they're gonna
make sure the exchange service's working

210
00:10:47.059 --> 00:10:50.697
okay, they are going to be looking
at all of the technical aspects.

211
00:10:50.697 --> 00:10:55.107
What we're interested in when we're
designing for experiences, we're

212
00:10:55.107 --> 00:11:00.830
interested in the customer experience,
because remember, value is perceived.

213
00:11:00.830 --> 00:11:02.832
That's what we're interested in.

214
00:11:02.832 --> 00:11:07.975
So we have to ensure, and
this happens way back in service strategy,

215
00:11:07.975 --> 00:11:12.620
it happens in the portfolio that
we map out our service model.

216
00:11:12.620 --> 00:11:17.278
And our service model is not just about
the components that make up a service, but

217
00:11:17.278 --> 00:11:19.687
it's also about those moments of truth.

218
00:11:19.687 --> 00:11:25.570
It's about understanding
the interactions in our service itself.

219
00:11:25.570 --> 00:11:33.345
It's about understanding exactly how
a customer will send and receive an email.

220
00:11:33.345 --> 00:11:35.290
It's about understanding
the moments of truth.

221
00:11:35.290 --> 00:11:38.938
And again, business relationship
management, it's gonna help us with this.

222
00:11:38.938 --> 00:11:41.684
You'll see as we go through
this particular section,

223
00:11:41.684 --> 00:11:45.340
that business relationship management
have a huge role to play in this.

224
00:11:46.630 --> 00:11:49.952
Because business relationship management
tell us what the customer is thinking.

225
00:11:49.952 --> 00:11:53.818
They tell us what the customer values and
what the users value and

226
00:11:53.818 --> 00:11:55.618
what the users are thinking.

227
00:11:55.618 --> 00:11:59.590

the getting out there.

00:24:27.706 --> 00:24:30.991
Get off your bum like Jo says and
even, this one girl,

00:24:30.991 --> 00:24:34.428
I remember I was doing a process
improvement project and

00:24:34.428 --> 00:24:37.990
she was such a nice girl,

00:24:37.990 --> 00:24:42.140

458
00:24:42.140 --> 00:24:44.540
And so here we have these great ideas and

00:24:44.540 --> 00:24:47.450
this resource that was
just being underutilized.

00:24:47.450 --> 00:24:50.220
>> Yeah, yeah, it happens all the time.

00:24:50.220 --> 00:24:53.090
Which is why we'll say you've got to
get off your bum, you've got to go and

00:24:53.090 --> 00:24:54.900
observe directly, you know.

463
00:24:54.900 --> 00:24:57.870
You've got to be able to,
I mean if we take a look at the slide.

00:24:57.870 --> 00:25:01.460
You know, identify blockages,
identify red tape.

465
00:25:01.460 --> 00:25:04.410
How do our customers

00:25:06.020 --> 00:25:10.639

previous slide and I said, how do you use,

00:25:10.639 --> 00:25:12.380
what about your customer experience?

468
00:25:12.380 --> 00:25:13.800
How do you send an email.

00:25:13.800 --> 00:25:16.520
Then you came out with all

00:25:16.520 --> 00:25:20.890
And yet what I observed when I got off my

00:25:20.890 --> 00:25:21.410
told me.

00:25:21.410 --> 00:25:22.850
>> Right.

473
00:25:22.850 --> 00:25:24.751
>> The other thing about
observing directly, or

00:25:24.751 --> 00:25:27.100
getting off your bum is
identify sources of resistance.

475
00:25:28.310 --> 00:25:31.225
Cuz I can only really find out
your attitude if I talk with you.

476
00:25:31.225 --> 00:25:33.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I don't talk to you,

477
00:25:33.730 --> 00:25:40.510
I don't get any sort of inclination as to
your attitude by looking at the survey.

478
00:25:40.510 --> 00:25:44.640
I only find out what your
attitude is by talking to you.

479
00:25:44.640 --> 00:25:49.570
So again, observing directly or getting
off your bum, really, really important.

480
00:25:51.210 --> 00:25:56.140
So let's take a look then at some
of our other guiding principles.

481
00:25:56.140 --> 00:25:59.630
And I love this one,
the being transparent guiding principle.

482
00:26:00.790 --> 00:26:03.880
We should do visible in
everything that we do.

483
00:26:03.880 --> 00:26:07.951
Now I'm not saying that you take top
secret information and tell everybody

484
00:26:07.951 --> 00:26:11.930
about the top secret information but
that third bullet point down.

485
00:26:11.930 --> 00:26:15.850
And we're gonna talk about this in a later
section in our communications section.

486
00:26:15.850 --> 00:26:20.129
The things that happens in secret,
this is when the rumors start and

487
00:26:20.129 --> 00:26:22.540
this is how you demoralize your team.

488
00:26:23.620 --> 00:26:26.240
How many changes have been implemented

489
00:26:26.240 --> 00:26:31.590
by the CIO of somebody seeing you stand
up and say hey we are going to do this.

490
00:26:31.590 --> 00:26:33.230
And then you don't hear anything else.

491
00:26:34.310 --> 00:26:36.470
And a year later,
something finally changes.

492
00:26:36.470 --> 00:26:39.832
Well, by that time you kinda switched
off and forgotten all about it and

493
00:26:39.832 --> 00:26:42.987
something suddenly happens and
you go, where did that come from?

494
00:26:44.556 --> 00:26:47.735
Things that happen in secret,
things that happen behind closed doors,

495
00:26:47.735 --> 00:26:49.800
that's how rumors start.

496
00:26:49.800 --> 00:26:54.030
So we need frequent communication but
not too frequent.

497
00:26:54.030 --> 00:26:58.350
We need to make sure that in order to get
people on board that we reward success.

498
00:26:58.350 --> 00:27:01.660
And we don't just take people
outside with a base ball bat and

499
00:27:01.660 --> 00:27:04.640
beat them when they're doing something
wrong that we actually acknowledge when

500
00:27:04.640 --> 00:27:05.810
they're doing something right.

501
00:27:07.590 --> 00:27:12.330
This is part of the all of
the principles to be perfectly honest is

502
00:27:12.330 --> 00:27:15.990
that collaboration,
getting people working together and

503
00:27:15.990 --> 00:27:20.000
again we've got communication
here that's really important.

504
00:27:20.000 --> 00:27:22.772
So we wanna use things like workshops and
meetings and

505
00:27:22.772 --> 00:27:26.120
brainstorm sections to get collaboration.

506
00:27:26.120 --> 00:27:27.760
We'll talk about this in OCM, but

507
00:27:27.760 --> 00:27:32.280
if you don't get people on board,
if you don't get people on your side

508
00:27:33.330 --> 00:27:36.870
then your implementation is
not going to be a success.

509
00:27:36.870 --> 00:27:39.990
And the easiest way to get
people on your side is to

510
00:27:39.990 --> 00:27:45.110
get them the responsibility is
to empower them to take action.

511
00:27:45.110 --> 00:27:51.460
If we don't empower them to take action
and to take responsibility, then,

512
00:27:51.460 --> 00:27:54.680
we're not gonna have them involved and
if we don't have them involved they could

513
00:27:54.680 --> 00:27:58.590
potentially be a source of resistance and
that's something that we don't want.

514
00:27:59.720 --> 00:28:01.840
Take notice of the bottom bullet point,

515
00:28:01.840 --> 00:28:05.700
you've heard that saying too
many cooks spoil the broth.

516
00:28:05.700 --> 00:28:07.786
Too much collaboration
can result in chaos, so

517
00:28:07.786 --> 00:28:10.718
you don't want everyone running
around like headless chickens.

518
00:28:10.718 --> 00:28:14.798
>> So ours is a lot like [LAUGH] I
haven't heard that saying since like

519
00:28:14.798 --> 00:28:16.776
too many cooks in the kitchen.

520
00:28:16.776 --> 00:28:17.660
>> All right, okay.

521
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:19.488
>> It's kind of shortened, I guess.

522
00:28:19.488 --> 00:28:21.152
We don't need to many
cooks in the kitchen.

523
00:28:21.152 --> 00:28:24.480
>> Right, yeah, we say too many cooks for
all the broth, yeah,

524
00:28:24.480 --> 00:28:26.695
cuz everybody's adding something in.

525
00:28:26.695 --> 00:28:29.450
And by the time-
>> You don't know what's in there.

526
00:28:29.450 --> 00:28:30.280
>> Yeah.

527
00:28:30.280 --> 00:28:33.525
And it probably tastes disgusting

528
00:28:33.525 --> 00:28:37.190
[LAUGH] So, yeah,
we don't wanna overcollaborate.

529
00:28:37.190 --> 00:28:40.610
We wanna make sure, and this is where
project management comes into it again and

530
00:28:40.610 --> 00:28:43.350
this is where the being
transparent comes into it.

531
00:28:43.350 --> 00:28:46.888
Because the project management means
that everything is planned and

532
00:28:46.888 --> 00:28:48.420
everything else is managed.

533
00:28:48.420 --> 00:28:54.363
And one person will know the involvement
and the input from everyone else,

534
00:28:54.363 --> 00:29:00.240
but also it means that nobody is
treading on anybody else's toes as well.

535
00:29:00.240 --> 00:29:05.700
And so that we have everybody involved but
only up to a certain level.

536
00:29:07.320 --> 00:29:11.030
And another one of my, and I keep saying
about, you know this one's my favorite and

537
00:29:11.030 --> 00:29:12.550
get off your bum's favorite.

538
00:29:12.550 --> 00:29:16.660
But this one, okay,
this one is glaringly obvious.

539
00:29:16.660 --> 00:29:18.610
Don't over engineer things.

540
00:29:18.610 --> 00:29:20.890
Keep it simple.

541
00:29:20.890 --> 00:29:24.450
We want to be efficient and
we want to be effective.

542
00:29:24.450 --> 00:29:27.810
The objective is always to deliver
value for our customers, always.

543
00:29:27.810 --> 00:29:29.620
No matter what we're doing.

544
00:29:29.620 --> 00:29:34.130

an improvement to reorganize our teams,

545
00:29:34.130 --> 00:29:37.560

an improvement in a process,

546
00:29:37.560 --> 00:29:41.090
whether we're working towards CMMI for
process maturity.

547
00:29:42.260 --> 00:29:45.464
Whatever we're doing,
we want to deliver value and

548
00:29:45.464 --> 00:29:49.710
over engineering anything is
never going to deliver value.

549
00:29:49.710 --> 00:29:52.940
If I have to as an end user,

00:29:56.164 --> 00:30:00.266

552

processes if I have to figure out what

553
00:30:04.830 --> 00:30:07.720

processes are every time I use it.

554
00:30:09.670 --> 00:30:13.690

555
00:30:13.690 --> 00:30:15.040
knowledge and wisdom.

556
00:30:16.280 --> 00:30:22.178

557
00:30:22.178 --> 00:30:27.503

558
00:30:27.503 --> 00:30:29.790
And the answer to that is no.

559
00:30:29.790 --> 00:30:30.890
Simple as that.

560
00:30:30.890 --> 00:30:33.490
No, if you cannot make
a decision from that report,

561
00:30:33.490 --> 00:30:34.940

562
00:30:34.940 --> 00:30:36.660

563
00:30:36.660 --> 00:30:40.430

564
00:30:40.430 --> 00:30:42.980
Am I going to use this
document in the future?

565
00:30:42.980 --> 00:30:46.140

566

00:30:51.940 --> 00:30:54.930

otherwise you can't use the principles,

00:31:09.020 --> 00:31:11.620

574
00:31:11.620 --> 00:31:15.110

we should be looking at

chart out to the organization,

00:17:57.460 --> 00:18:03.890

00:18:03.890 --> 00:18:09.180

00:18:09.180 --> 00:18:10.900

323
00:18:10.900 --> 00:18:13.480
We've got to have to do
some reports with money.

324
00:18:13.480 --> 00:18:16.790
We've got to have some reports that
the customers are interested in.

325
00:18:16.790 --> 00:18:20.040
We've got to have reports
that are internal to us.

326
00:18:20.040 --> 00:18:22.630
And of course think about language and
communication and

00:18:22.630 --> 00:18:24.210
they'll be in our language.

328
00:18:25.280 --> 00:18:28.270
And then we've got to have reports that
show what we're doing in the future,

329
00:18:28.270 --> 00:18:29.960
cuz we don't want to stagnate.

330
00:18:31.810 --> 00:18:36.110
And there's a lot to think about
when it comes to reporting.

331
00:18:36.110 --> 00:18:39.790
Also, think about the types of
metrics that we're going to have.

332
00:18:39.790 --> 00:18:43.950
So technology metrics, well,
if I go back to this particular diagram,

00:18:43.950 --> 00:18:47.520
technology metrics are going to be
an internal metric, aren't they?

334
00:18:47.520 --> 00:18:48.880
Or are they?

335
00:18:48.880 --> 00:18:53.520
Cuz technology metrics will include
failure, for instance, of our laptops and

336
00:18:53.520 --> 00:18:54.520
our desktops.

337
00:18:54.520 --> 00:18:57.440
That would be a technology metric.

338
00:18:57.440 --> 00:18:59.510
How often does something fail?

339
00:18:59.510 --> 00:19:03.980
Whereas, a process would be how
quickly does incident management

00:19:03.980 --> 00:19:09.560
respond to that failure or how quickly do
we restore service after that failure?

341
00:19:09.560 --> 00:19:10.580
So surely,

342
00:19:10.580 --> 00:19:15.120
if I go back to the balance score card,
then both of them are customer views.

343
00:19:15.120 --> 00:19:19.070
But they're also internal views
because there's technology view there.

344
00:19:19.070 --> 00:19:21.480
Now what about the cost of the incident?

345
00:19:21.480 --> 00:19:24.053
Well, that would be a process metric, but

346
00:19:24.053 --> 00:19:27.295
that would be if
a financial metric as well.

347
00:19:27.295 --> 00:19:31.015
And then an innovation metric would
be okay, so what I'm I going to doing

348
00:19:31.015 --> 00:19:35.065
in terms of actually preventing
this from happening again?

349
00:19:35.065 --> 00:19:37.435
I might be replacing that laptop.

350
00:19:39.190 --> 00:19:40.630
There's a balance to be had.

351
00:19:40.630 --> 00:19:42.460
And we talk about tension.

352
00:19:42.460 --> 00:19:45.920
In other words having a balance
between people and money and

353
00:19:45.920 --> 00:19:49.730
having a balance with functionality and
having a balance with time.

354
00:19:49.730 --> 00:19:54.670
But ultimately what you will see,
and this is where it can get quite

355
00:19:54.670 --> 00:19:59.570
confusing for everybody, is that what you
will see is that we've got a balance not

356
00:19:59.570 --> 00:20:04.270
only between technology and process and
therefore the end to end service.

357
00:20:04.270 --> 00:20:08.530
But also, we've got a balance
between our views as well.

358
00:20:08.530 --> 00:20:11.860
And then we've got to consider
the reasons why we measure.

359
00:20:13.200 --> 00:20:15.310
We haven't even started
talking about metrics yet,

360
00:20:16.590 --> 00:20:18.450
because there's still a lot more to cover.

361
00:20:19.910 --> 00:20:23.120
So right now then, we've looked at so

362
00:20:23.120 --> 00:20:26.790
far, in this episode,
we've looked at why we measure.

363
00:20:26.790 --> 00:20:30.030
We've looked at having a balanced
view on what we measure and

364
00:20:30.030 --> 00:20:33.880
the tension metrics ensuring
we maintain that balance.

365
00:20:33.880 --> 00:20:38.690
And we've looked at the types of metric,
but then look else why we measure,

366
00:20:38.690 --> 00:20:43.580
which is we measure because
we want to show progress and

367
00:20:43.580 --> 00:20:45.960
we might show progress on a project.

368
00:20:45.960 --> 00:20:49.610
This is why we have a Gantt chart,
for instance in project management.

369
00:20:49.610 --> 00:20:52.467
We measure because we
want to show compliance.

370
00:20:52.467 --> 00:20:56.690
We also measure because we want to
show efficiency of our processes and

371
00:20:56.690 --> 00:20:58.400
efficiency of our services.

372
00:20:58.400 --> 00:21:02.110
And we also measure it because
we want to show effectiveness.

373
00:21:02.110 --> 00:21:08.470
Also in other words, does a service
do what it's supposed to do?

374
00:21:08.470 --> 00:21:12.430
So for now, what I'd like you to do for
this particular episode

00:21:12.430 --> 00:21:16.650
