in your downloadable material.

376
00:21:16.650 --> 00:21:20.165
I would like you to review
these slides again.

377
00:21:20.165 --> 00:21:22.500
I'd like you to review this material,

And we're going to expand that view

382
00:21:40.030 --> 00:21:45.560
As I said, you're going to be tested

383
00:21:45.560 --> 00:21:49.720
But more importantly than that,

if you're trying to implement ITIL or

00:22:06.490 --> 00:22:08.100

We have to be able to make

390
00:22:11.590 --> 00:22:15.640
So so far, in this particular episode,

391
00:22:15.640 --> 00:22:16.790
And in our next episode,

392
00:22:16.790 --> 00:22:20.320

393
00:22:20.320 --> 00:22:21.560
>> All right, Jo, sounds like a plan.

394
00:22:21.560 --> 00:22:24.000
So ladies and gentlemen,
stay tuned for more metrics and

396

00:22:27.550 --> 00:22:28.910

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee begin by defining specific metric types. Jo explains the difference between leading, trailing, outside-in, and inside-out metrics. She also shows how scorecards influence service reporting. Next, you will see how to leverage reports and assessments through the use of tools like gap analysis and CMMI levels.

00:19:55.850 --> 00:19:58.079
to our competitors, for instance.

385
00:19:59.520 --> 00:20:02.880
An assessment will give us an objective
perspective, as it says here,

386
00:20:02.880 --> 00:20:04.140
of our current state.

387
00:20:05.750 --> 00:20:10.767
And we might use something like CMMI
which is a commonly accepted or

388
00:20:10.767 --> 00:20:13.554
a universally accepted framework.

389
00:20:13.554 --> 00:20:18.783
But it's only gonna give you a point
in time assessment of where we are.

390
00:20:18.783 --> 00:20:23.012
So if you want to actually use that to
make an improvement, then you have to

391
00:20:23.012 --> 00:20:27.260
assess before, which is our baseline,
before we make any improvement.

392
00:20:27.260 --> 00:20:31.440
And we assess after we've made
the improvement to see whether we have

393
00:20:31.440 --> 00:20:33.950
actually made that improvement.

394
00:20:35.070 --> 00:20:38.614
Just be really, really careful because
if you're doing an assessment and

395
00:20:38.614 --> 00:20:40.761
that's an assessment against a framework.

396
00:20:40.761 --> 00:20:44.111
Then you might be trying
to skew the figures,

397
00:20:44.111 --> 00:20:49.040
to make it look as though you're
better than you really are.

398
00:20:49.040 --> 00:20:52.030
Or even to make it look
worse than you really are.

399
00:20:52.030 --> 00:20:56.020
And I've seen that happen as well,
so be really careful.

400
00:20:56.020 --> 00:21:00.870
And sometimes with these assessments, we
will advise and again, there are pros and

401
00:21:00.870 --> 00:21:01.710
cons, advantages and

402
00:21:01.710 --> 00:21:04.551
disadvantages in using an internal person-
>> Right.

403
00:21:04.551 --> 00:21:07.295
>> To perform an assessment or
a benchmark.

404
00:21:07.295 --> 00:21:09.231
>> Just to remain totally objective there.

405
00:21:09.231 --> 00:21:12.680
>> Right, yeah, an internal person's
not going to remain totally objective.

406
00:21:12.680 --> 00:21:15.349
They're always going to
approach an assessment with

407
00:21:16.810 --> 00:21:18.860
some form of objective in mind.

408
00:21:18.860 --> 00:21:19.840
So it's going to be very,

409
00:21:19.840 --> 00:21:23.770
very subjective, whereas an external
person is gonna cost more.

410
00:21:23.770 --> 00:21:27.241
And the problem with an external person is
that they don't understand your business

411
00:21:27.241 --> 00:21:27.880
environment.

412
00:21:27.880 --> 00:21:31.940
However, an external person performing
an assessment is always going to give you

413
00:21:31.940 --> 00:21:34.560
a completely objective view.

414
00:21:34.560 --> 00:21:39.514
So you're going to get an accurate view
and a realistic view of where you are.

415
00:21:39.514 --> 00:21:41.778
I mean,
you might use all of this information,

416
00:21:41.778 --> 00:21:44.033
these reports to perform a gap analysis.

417
00:21:44.033 --> 00:21:48.570
And a gap analysis is just really a form
of assessment which is where we take our

418
00:21:48.570 --> 00:21:53.240
baseline and
we then compare it to where we want to be.

419
00:21:53.240 --> 00:21:56.520
In other words, let's say for
process maturity,

420
00:21:56.520 --> 00:21:59.110
we're at level two on a CMMI scale.

421
00:21:59.110 --> 00:22:03.797
And level two is just that, well,
we have some formal procedure in place and

422
00:22:03.797 --> 00:22:06.226
it's being followed most of the time.

423
00:22:06.226 --> 00:22:08.090
>> And we start at a level one, right?

424
00:22:08.090 --> 00:22:09.185
>> We start at level zero.

425
00:22:09.185 --> 00:22:12.233
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> And then it goes up to five, and

426
00:22:12.233 --> 00:22:14.950
five would be what we'd want to achieve?

427
00:22:14.950 --> 00:22:18.732
>> Five is where a process is subject
to continual service improvement.

428
00:22:18.732 --> 00:22:23.832
So five is where our process is so
mature that we are actively looking for

429
00:22:23.832 --> 00:22:27.324
ways to improve that
process on a regular basis.

430
00:22:27.324 --> 00:22:28.175
>> Okay.

431
00:22:28.175 --> 00:22:30.587
>> So we have various different, and

432
00:22:30.587 --> 00:22:34.665
by all means look it up on the Internet-
>> Yeah, we've talked about this,

433
00:22:34.665 --> 00:22:36.592
I just wanted to kind of remember because,
yeah.

434
00:22:36.592 --> 00:22:45.250
>> Yeah, and CMMI is not something that
we would tell you that you have to use.

435
00:22:45.250 --> 00:22:49.600
But it's another improvement
technique that you can use.

436
00:22:49.600 --> 00:22:51.590
It's for assessments, as we say.

437
00:22:51.590 --> 00:22:55.380
And it's available freely on the Internet,

438
00:22:55.380 --> 00:22:57.380
so there's no reason why
you wouldn't use it.

439
00:22:57.380 --> 00:23:02.560
It's not something that you
would have to have training in.

440
00:23:02.560 --> 00:23:07.870
It's not something that you have
to sort of attend a class for

441
00:23:07.870 --> 00:23:12.000
three weeks or whatever and then achieve
a certain level of qualification in.

442
00:23:12.000 --> 00:23:15.310
It's really simple in that we will use it

443
00:23:15.310 --> 00:23:18.620
just to give us a snapshot of where
we are right now with our processes.

444
00:23:18.620 --> 00:23:22.958
And it will tell us that actually, we're
only on a level between a level one and

445
00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:25.603
level two and
that our process is fairly ad hoc.

446
00:23:25.603 --> 00:23:28.025
And we know that really
where we need to be for

447
00:23:28.025 --> 00:23:30.570
our organization is
probably at level four.

448
00:23:30.570 --> 00:23:34.000
Where we don't necessarily need
CSI in place right now but

449
00:23:34.000 --> 00:23:37.105
we do need to have a process
that everybody's aware of,

450
00:23:37.105 --> 00:23:39.790
that it's communicated and
everybody's following it.

451
00:23:39.790 --> 00:23:41.720
And it's measured and managed.

452
00:23:41.720 --> 00:23:44.670
So that would give us
then that gap analysis.

453
00:23:44.670 --> 00:23:47.548
And the gap analysis is just looking
at where we are right now and

454
00:23:47.548 --> 00:23:49.676
then comparing it against
where we want to be.

455
00:23:49.676 --> 00:23:52.045
Just shows us how much
work we've got to do.

456
00:23:52.045 --> 00:23:54.570
And you can do a gap analysis-
>> Identifying the gap, yeah.

457
00:23:54.570 --> 00:23:57.752
>> Right,
you can do a gap analysis on people.

458
00:23:57.752 --> 00:23:59.791
Our skills, that's a gap analysis.

459
00:23:59.791 --> 00:24:04.424
You can do a gap analysis on our
processes and on our technology as well.

460
00:24:04.424 --> 00:24:08.795
Any improvement, there's gonna be some
form of gap analysis there because even

461
00:24:08.795 --> 00:24:12.908
with the CSI approach, we looked at
this in a previous episode, with the CSI

462
00:24:12.908 --> 00:24:17.520
approach, we work out where are we
right now and where do we want to be?

463
00:24:17.520 --> 00:24:19.290
Okay, and now, how am I gonna get there?

464
00:24:19.290 --> 00:24:25.112
>> So when we're sitting in yoga class,
we can just be like, gap analysis.

465
00:24:25.112 --> 00:24:26.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Maybe.

466
00:24:26.250 --> 00:24:27.100
>> Whether we wanna be.

467
00:24:27.100 --> 00:24:30.224
Yeah, but some of us don't
actually sit in yoga class.

468
00:24:30.224 --> 00:24:30.841
[LAUGH]
>> I don't either.

469
00:24:30.841 --> 00:24:33.580
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

470
00:24:33.580 --> 00:24:36.590
we might want to and
I've already mentioned this benchmark.

471
00:24:36.590 --> 00:24:40.520
A benchmark is a comparison
against our competitors or

472
00:24:40.520 --> 00:24:43.095
a comparison against an industry standard.

473
00:24:44.710 --> 00:24:46.495
When I will tell you.

474
00:24:46.495 --> 00:24:49.565
And our next slide looks at
the benefits of benchmarking.

475
00:24:49.565 --> 00:24:54.585
It really is about us gaining an objective
view, objective being the key

476
00:24:54.585 --> 00:24:59.785
word in this, and comparing it to
others within the industry and

477
00:24:59.785 --> 00:25:03.585
to say whether it's competitors or
whether it's an industry standard.

478
00:25:03.585 --> 00:25:05.245
It has to be objective.

479
00:25:05.245 --> 00:25:08.215
And I will always,
always add in this huge,

480
00:25:08.215 --> 00:25:10.555
big caveat when it comes to benchmarking.

481
00:25:12.070 --> 00:25:14.400
We can do an assessment for
instance against,

482
00:25:14.400 --> 00:25:16.640
let's say our incidence
management process.

483
00:25:16.640 --> 00:25:21.260
And we can assess that our incidence
management process is on level

484
00:25:21.260 --> 00:25:22.800
three of the CMMI scale.

485
00:25:23.920 --> 00:25:27.000
And then we might benchmark that
against industry standards for

486
00:25:27.000 --> 00:25:28.610
our particular industry.

487
00:25:28.610 --> 00:25:32.530
And we might say that everybody else in
our industry is showing a level two and

488
00:25:32.530 --> 00:25:37.370
a half against the CMMI scale, but

489
00:25:37.370 --> 00:25:40.380
just because we're showing a level
three doesn't that we're any good.

490
00:25:40.380 --> 00:25:43.500
It just means that we're doing
better than everybody else.

491
00:25:45.090 --> 00:25:49.980
And if we're showing a level two,
well it doesn't mean that we're bad.

492
00:25:49.980 --> 00:25:52.330
It just means that we're
worse than everybody else.

493
00:25:53.990 --> 00:25:59.650
You've got to be very careful because
the benchmark could be your basis for

494
00:25:59.650 --> 00:26:01.690
boosting self-confidence as it says there.

495
00:26:01.690 --> 00:26:06.898
It could be a basis for giving our
customers trust and evidence that we're

496
00:26:06.898 --> 00:26:12.280
actually doing really well because
we're better than our competitors.

497
00:26:12.280 --> 00:26:14.590
But it can also have
the opposite effect as well.

498
00:26:16.260 --> 00:26:20.120
You've got to be really careful because,
just cuz a benchmark tells you that you're

499
00:26:20.120 --> 00:26:24.130
doing better than your competitors doesn't
actually mean that you're doing well.

500
00:26:24.130 --> 00:26:26.930
And just because a benchmark tells you
you're doing worse than your competitors

501
00:26:26.930 --> 00:26:30.840
doesn't really mean that you're
doing particularly badly either.

502
00:26:30.840 --> 00:26:32.580
So be careful with benchmarking.

503
00:26:34.250 --> 00:26:39.920
Benchmarking is about being
able to compare maybe costs,

504
00:26:39.920 --> 00:26:44.310
maybe comparing efficiency,
maybe comparing effectiveness.

505
00:26:44.310 --> 00:26:48.200
But all I would tell you
is that benchmarking well

506
00:26:48.200 --> 00:26:50.770
If you're going to do it,
consider the relevance.

507
00:26:50.770 --> 00:26:54.020
Consider the reasoning
behind the benchmarking.

508
00:26:54.020 --> 00:26:57.840
And think about objectively what it
is you're trying to achieve from that

509
00:26:57.840 --> 00:27:02.070
benchmark before you undertake
the benchmarking process itself.

510
00:27:02.070 --> 00:27:05.220
Because benchmarking,
it's not insignificant.

511
00:27:05.220 --> 00:27:07.610
It's something that's gonna
take some time to do.

512
00:27:07.610 --> 00:27:11.340
So think about what you're trying to
achieve before you undertake the exercise.

513
00:27:13.120 --> 00:27:15.770
So now we've looked at metrics and
we've looked at measurements and

514
00:27:15.770 --> 00:27:19.540
we've looked at assessments and we've
looked at having balance in our metrics.

515
00:27:21.250 --> 00:27:23.940
You have,
within your downloadable materials,

516
00:27:23.940 --> 00:27:28.610
quite a few exercises now looking
at metrics and measurements.

517
00:27:29.820 --> 00:27:35.720
Now I can tell you and I already have,
that from a standpoint of your exam,

518
00:27:35.720 --> 00:27:39.840
you're going to get between six and
12 questions on metrics and measurements.

519
00:27:39.840 --> 00:27:43.420
And they're going to test that you
understand how important it is

520
00:27:43.420 --> 00:27:46.790
to have that balance between
all of your metrics.

521
00:27:46.790 --> 00:27:51.348
And insure that you do have
a balance between inside-out and

522
00:27:51.348 --> 00:27:53.430
outside-in, and leading and trailing.

523
00:27:53.430 --> 00:27:58.280
And that you're able to display
metrics and obtain metrics from

524
00:27:58.280 --> 00:28:03.780
a balanced score card view and that you'll
measure progress and compliance and

525
00:28:03.780 --> 00:28:07.280
effectiveness and efficiency and
you understand why you're measuring.

526
00:28:08.470 --> 00:28:14.720
So my recommendation to you now is
to review our previous two episodes,

527
00:28:14.720 --> 00:28:17.970
last episode and this episode, again.

528
00:28:17.970 --> 00:28:22.100
Take a look at the slides that you have
downloaded in your downloadable material

529
00:28:22.100 --> 00:28:29.290
and then undertake the practice exercises
within your downloadable material.

530
00:28:29.290 --> 00:28:33.950
If you have any questions at all, then
please get in touch with us via the forum.

531
00:28:33.950 --> 00:28:37.260
And I will be happy to help
you out as best as I can.

532
00:28:37.260 --> 00:28:37.920
>> Well, thank you, Jo.

533
00:28:37.920 --> 00:28:39.690
And thank you for joining us as well.

534
00:28:39.690 --> 00:28:42.330
But stay tuned,
we have a lot more headed your way.

535
00:28:42.330 --> 00:28:44.160
We'll go ahead and sign out for this show.

536
00:28:44.160 --> 00:28:45.690
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

537
00:28:45.690 --> 00:28:46.530
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

538
00:28:46.530 --> 00:28:49.055
>> See you next time, here at ITProTV.

539
00:28:49.055 --> 00:28:54.863
[MUSIC]

540
00:28:54.863 --> 00:28:58.189
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain organizational change management. This approach may be different from what you think about when it comes to change management.  When it comes to Organizational Change Management  Jo  stresses it is essential to focus on the people to become successful. Jo also shares tools such as The Gartner Hype Cycle,  Bridges Phases of Transition,  JP Kotter's 8 Steps to help understand what individuals go thru during a time of change.  Lastly, they look at ways to help identify resistance.
episodes.title: Organizational Change Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:02.320
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.320 --> 00:00:06.690
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.690 --> 00:00:08.335
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.335 --> 00:00:11.834
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.834 --> 00:00:15.290
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen
to your ITIL Practitioner Series.

6
00:00:15.290 --> 00:00:17.400
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.400 --> 00:00:21.390
In this episode we'll be taking a look
at organizational change management.

8
00:00:21.390 --> 00:00:24.570
And back in studios with us
today we have Mrs. Joe Peacock.

9
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:25.620
How's it going Joe?

10
00:00:25.620 --> 00:00:27.130
>> Absolutely great, thank you Cherokee.

11
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:27.780
How are you?

12
00:00:27.780 --> 00:00:28.820
>> I'm doing excellent.

13
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:29.417
Thank you.

14
00:00:29.417 --> 00:00:32.490
Now I know a lot the different
topics that we've discuss Joe,

15
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:35.386
we've taken it we might have
seen this topics before, but

16
00:00:35.386 --> 00:00:38.870
here we're looking at it from
a practitioners perspective.

17
00:00:38.870 --> 00:00:42.665
So how does that really affect when
we're looking at organizational change

18
00:00:42.665 --> 00:00:43.382
management?

19
00:00:43.382 --> 00:00:46.380
And what would be some of these
big discrepancies or differences?

20
00:00:46.380 --> 00:00:49.050
>> Okay, well the first thing you've got
to do is understand what organizational

21
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:50.470
change management is.

22
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:51.324
>> Sounds like a good idea.

23
00:00:51.324 --> 00:00:52.759
[LAUGH]
>> Right, okay.

24
00:00:52.759 --> 00:00:56.777
There is a huge big difference between
organizational change management and

25
00:00:56.777 --> 00:00:58.765
change management that we know in IT.

26
00:00:58.765 --> 00:01:03.344
And change management that we
looked at in service transition,

27
00:01:03.344 --> 00:01:08.003
we looked at the change to a configuration
item of CI or a service or

28
00:01:08.003 --> 00:01:12.435
the change to perhaps a process,
or change to a document etc.

29
00:01:12.435 --> 00:01:15.553
Now all of those would be
covered by change management.

30
00:01:15.553 --> 00:01:20.512
In all of those instances and examples we
would raise an RFC request for change,

31
00:01:20.512 --> 00:01:24.215
which would be recorded and
documented as change record.

32
00:01:24.215 --> 00:01:25.864
And I call login system, and

33
00:01:25.864 --> 00:01:30.560
then it would be progressed through that
particular life cycle of that process.

34
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:33.090
This is completely different.

35
00:01:34.180 --> 00:01:37.510
Organizational change management
is all about actually looking at

36
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:39.390
the people side of changes.

37
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:42.150
>> Okay.
>> It's about understanding people, and

38
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:46.180
it's about managing people through change.

39
00:01:46.180 --> 00:01:50.840
And really just to understand in
the people either make or break a change.

40
00:01:50.840 --> 00:01:53.879
People will either be the success or
failure to any change.

41
00:01:53.879 --> 00:01:57.080
And so we've got to accept that and
we've got to deal with that.

42
00:01:58.180 --> 00:02:02.750
Way too often in IT we look at
the technical side of things and

43
00:02:02.750 --> 00:02:05.150
we might even look at the process and
the documentation.

44
00:02:05.150 --> 00:02:10.390
I mean let’s face it we've all got control
in place for updating documentation.

45
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:13.470
We've got controls in place for
the updating of our services.

46
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:18.050
So when we wanna update a document,
we never overwrite the previous version.

47
00:02:18.050 --> 00:02:21.280
We take a copy of it and
we save it as something else.

48
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:23.160
We do the same with our files on our PCs.

49
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:27.570
We do exactly the same when
we're bringing in a new service.

50
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:31.980
We don't ever change version one
of any particular application.

51
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:35.430
We'll take a copy of version one and
then we'll make the changes to it and

52
00:02:35.430 --> 00:02:39.960
we'll save that as version 2 or
is version 1.1, depending on

53
00:02:39.960 --> 00:02:44.450
our naming convention and depending on
what it is that we've actually changed.

54
00:02:44.450 --> 00:02:47.390
So we look at the technical
aspect to any change but

55
00:02:47.390 --> 00:02:53.180
we never really spend any time looking
at the people aspect of change,

56
00:02:53.180 --> 00:02:57.740
on the people aspect of any
implementation at all, and yet,

57
00:02:57.740 --> 00:03:01.190
it's the people that we're
expecting to do the work.

58
00:03:01.190 --> 00:03:03.470
When it's the people that
we're expecting to what,

59
00:03:03.470 --> 00:03:07.480
just miraculously be on board with
whatever it is you're trying to achieve.

60
00:03:07.480 --> 00:03:08.030
>> Right.

61
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:12.590
>> Yeah, is that what you're doing,
because in a sense that's exactly what we

62
00:03:12.590 --> 00:03:16.657
do in IT, we forget about the people,
and we just think that if we've

63
00:03:16.657 --> 00:03:21.239
got the right processes in place,
then the people are just gonna come along.

64
00:03:21.239 --> 00:03:25.775
>> I've actually been in a situation Joe
where our superior literally just handed

65
00:03:25.775 --> 00:03:27.602
us the book and move my cheese and

66
00:03:27.602 --> 00:03:32.430
that was about it That was the extent of
their organizational change management.

67
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:34.599
>> Let me tell you a little secret then.

68
00:03:34.599 --> 00:03:39.270
[LAUGH] Because I have something,
I have something to tell you on that.

69
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:44.629
I was working a few years ago now, I was
actually doing some work in Los Angeles.

70
00:03:44.629 --> 00:03:47.965
And now I'm British in case you
hadn't guessed by the accent, okay?

71
00:03:47.965 --> 00:03:48.725

then you might actually change
the work that they have to do.

525
00:29:06.241 --> 00:29:10.581
That means that you have to change their
working hours, which means that the things

526
00:29:10.581 --> 00:29:14.301
that they used to do on an evening now
is part of that work right balance,

527
00:29:14.301 --> 00:29:15.740
they might have to change.

528
00:29:16.840 --> 00:29:21.160
So think about those implications because
that'll be a source of resistance if you

529
00:29:21.160 --> 00:29:21.662
don't.

530
00:29:21.662 --> 00:29:25.468
And of course there is
a loss of face as well.

531
00:29:25.468 --> 00:29:28.690
And that's something that you
desperately need to consider.

532
00:29:28.690 --> 00:29:33.474
When it comes to if you're
changing roles for certain people.

533
00:29:33.474 --> 00:29:36.133
Then it could be perceived as being maybe

534
00:29:36.133 --> 00:29:38.660
a step down-
>> If it's emotion yeah like

535
00:29:38.660 --> 00:29:39.930
you're embarrassed.

536
00:29:39.930 --> 00:29:42.480
>> Right, a sideways step,
something like that.

537
00:29:42.480 --> 00:29:44.585
So be very aware of that.

538
00:29:44.585 --> 00:29:46.436
And then there's always that fear,

539
00:29:46.436 --> 00:29:49.370
regarding sort of the competence
level of that as well.

540
00:29:49.370 --> 00:29:52.329
You're doing this because I'm
not very good at my work?

541
00:29:52.329 --> 00:29:54.125
Is that why you're doing this?

542
00:29:54.125 --> 00:29:59.473
Now, the ripples effect,
when I talk about Ripples,

543
00:29:59.473 --> 00:30:05.402
what I actually mean here is
the fact that if I'm uncertain,

544
00:30:05.402 --> 00:30:11.099
if I'm really,
really weary about the safety of my role,

545
00:30:11.099 --> 00:30:13.914
then I'm gonna talk to you.

546
00:30:13.914 --> 00:30:17.860
And if I'm talking to you about the fact
that I'm feeling slightly uncomfortable-

547
00:30:17.860 --> 00:30:19.452
>> I'm gonna wonder about my job.

548
00:30:19.452 --> 00:30:21.491
>> You're gonna wonder about yours, and

549
00:30:21.491 --> 00:30:23.847
then you're gonna go
talk to somebody else.

550
00:30:23.847 --> 00:30:26.529
And that person might talk to two or
three people, and then they might talk,

551
00:30:26.529 --> 00:30:27.910
>> It's like an infection yeah.

552
00:30:27.910 --> 00:30:30.920
>> Right and that's why we call it,
it's that ripple effect.

553
00:30:30.920 --> 00:30:34.750
It's like that stone dropping in the pond,
that just creates ripples out.

554
00:30:36.040 --> 00:30:41.220
And the problem is that if it's that
one bad room and you see one person.

555
00:30:41.220 --> 00:30:46.230
One negative person can
undermine the attitudes

556
00:30:46.230 --> 00:30:48.870
of 500 people within the organization.

557
00:30:49.900 --> 00:30:53.320
So we've gotta be very
careful in our communication.

558
00:30:53.320 --> 00:30:55.385
We've gotta get that message right, and

559
00:30:55.385 --> 00:30:58.046
we've got to overcome these
sources of resistance.

560
00:30:58.046 --> 00:31:02.570
We've also got to overcome any of
the emotional cycle of change as

561
00:31:02.570 --> 00:31:04.140
quickly as possible.

562
00:31:04.140 --> 00:31:05.981
So we've got to know about this.

563
00:31:05.981 --> 00:31:11.175
People wonder about things that
am I not gonna have more to do?

564
00:31:11.175 --> 00:31:13.660
And don't forget past resentments as well.

565
00:31:13.660 --> 00:31:17.130
I don't wanna work with you I mean no
offense but I really don't like you and

566
00:31:17.130 --> 00:31:18.490
I don't wanna work with you.

567
00:31:18.490 --> 00:31:21.180
And the fact that we're
being put together in a team

568
00:31:21.180 --> 00:31:24.160
now with each other really
what do they expect from us?

569
00:31:24.160 --> 00:31:28.324
I mean come on get real this could happen.

570
00:31:28.324 --> 00:31:31.394
We want to work in an efficient and
effective way.

571
00:31:31.394 --> 00:31:34.004
It's never gonna be an efficient
way to put Cherokee and

572
00:31:34.004 --> 00:31:35.400
I together on team all right.

573
00:31:35.400 --> 00:31:37.452
It's just not gonna happen.

574
00:31:37.452 --> 00:31:38.710
So, think about this.

575
00:31:38.710 --> 00:31:46.010
You know, personal conflict and personal,
how do we say this, attitudes etc.

576
00:31:46.010 --> 00:31:50.870
As much as management can turn around and
say, you're both adults,

577
00:31:50.870 --> 00:31:52.250
you should both get over this.

578
00:31:52.250 --> 00:31:57.064
The simple fact of the matter is,
that if you are managing a change,

579
00:31:57.064 --> 00:32:01.963
if you are managing an implementation and
you put two people together

580
00:32:01.963 --> 00:32:06.890
who don't work together,
who don't really get on with each other.

581
00:32:06.890 --> 00:32:09.422
Then I don't care how much
you might wanna sit back and

582
00:32:09.422 --> 00:32:13.680
smugly think to yourself, it's okay
they're adults they can deal with this.

583
00:32:13.680 --> 00:32:17.070
The simple fact of the matter is you're
not gonna get 100% out of them so

584
00:32:17.070 --> 00:32:17.890
why are you going it?

585
00:32:19.660 --> 00:32:20.780
Think about this.

586
00:32:20.780 --> 00:32:23.830
The responsibility is on
you as the project manager.

587
00:32:23.830 --> 00:32:28.527
The responsibility is not on
the two of them because you

588
00:32:28.527 --> 00:32:32.215
knew about that issue before you did this.

589
00:32:32.215 --> 00:32:36.310
And just turn around to people inside
you're gonna have to get along with each

590
00:32:36.310 --> 00:32:37.701
other is not good enough.

591
00:32:37.701 --> 00:32:40.599
And then of course there
are the real threats, and

592
00:32:40.599 --> 00:32:43.510
sometimes the real spread as well.

593
00:32:43.510 --> 00:32:48.044
They can get lost in all
of the supposed threats.

594
00:32:48.044 --> 00:32:52.650
They can get lost in all of the rumors
well we don't know nobody can workout

595
00:32:52.650 --> 00:32:57.333
what's real and what's not real and
it leads to speculation and rumors and

596
00:32:57.333 --> 00:33:01.480
that could be very,
very not just disconcerting for people.

597
00:33:01.480 --> 00:33:07.209
But that can have a real effect on the
mind and success of any implementation.

598
00:33:07.209 --> 00:33:11.378
In our next section, we're going to go
a little bit further into communication.

599
00:33:11.378 --> 00:33:16.095
And we're going to talk more about how
we actually communicate with people and

600
00:33:16.095 --> 00:33:19.238
how we try and
avoid the emotional cycle of change and

601
00:33:19.238 --> 00:33:22.660
how we avoid that neutral
zone that we saw.

602
00:33:22.660 --> 00:33:25.910
Because communication
is key to all of this.

603
00:33:25.910 --> 00:33:30.613
But nevertheless in this particular
section, we've looked at the people

604
00:33:30.613 --> 00:33:35.236
side of things and I want you to bear
in mind that the people side of things,

605
00:33:35.236 --> 00:33:38.295
has to be a huge big part
of any implementation and

606
00:33:38.295 --> 00:33:41.302
of any improvement initiative and
any change.

607
00:33:41.302 --> 00:33:45.704
And if you ignore the people side of
things, then your implementation and

608
00:33:45.704 --> 00:33:47.979
your change will simply not succeed.

609
00:33:47.979 --> 00:33:50.481
So we have to consider this.

610
00:33:50.481 --> 00:33:53.010
So for our next section,
as I've already said,

611
00:33:53.010 --> 00:33:57.082
in our next episode we're gonna take
a look further at communication and how we

612
00:33:57.082 --> 00:34:01.630
actually communicate with each other and
our communication principles within ITIL.

613
00:34:01.630 --> 00:34:02.920
But for now,

614
00:34:02.920 --> 00:34:07.040
we're just going to leave organizational
change management exactly where we are.

615
00:34:07.040 --> 00:34:08.250
>> Sounds like a good idea Jo,

616
00:34:08.250 --> 00:34:11.620
thank you for taking the time to
explain to us that difference.

617
00:34:11.620 --> 00:34:13.253
And thank you for joining us as well but

618
00:34:13.253 --> 00:34:15.561
stay tuned we have more
information headed your way.

619
00:34:15.561 --> 00:34:18.110
We'll go ahead and sign out for this show.

620
00:34:18.110 --> 00:34:19.325
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

621
00:34:19.325 --> 00:34:20.430
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

622
00:34:20.430 --> 00:34:22.657
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

623
00:34:22.657 --> 00:34:28.617
[MUSIC]

624
00:34:28.617 --> 00:34:31.889
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee  explain how communication is a two-way process. Although, we are communicating through various avenues all the time , Jo outlines specific communication methods such as a Stakeholder Communication Plan. Timing and frequency are also explained in addition to various additional points. Lastly, they look at an example communication path.
episodes.title: Communication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:06.560
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pizet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.560 --> 00:00:08.443
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.443 --> 00:00:11.962
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.962 --> 00:00:15.249
>> Welcome back ladies and gentlemen
to your ITIL practitioner series.

5
00:00:15.249 --> 00:00:17.403
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.403 --> 00:00:22.108
In this episode,
we will be talking about communication.

7
00:00:22.108 --> 00:00:24.845
[LAUGH] I feel like SpongeBob,
I should have a little rainbow.

8
00:00:24.845 --> 00:00:26.896
Communication.

9
00:00:26.896 --> 00:00:28.716
[LAUGH] I don't know if you
know what I'm talking about.

10
00:00:28.716 --> 00:00:29.435
>> I haven't got a clue.

11
00:00:29.435 --> 00:00:30.350
>> But anyways-
>> Nope.

12
00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:33.144
>> I'm really hoping that you
can enlighten me on this.

13
00:00:33.144 --> 00:00:36.267
Because it is a pretty broad topic,
and it is a really important one.

14
00:00:36.267 --> 00:00:38.484
So exactly,
what will we be focusing in on?

15
00:00:38.484 --> 00:00:40.182
>> Well, in that particular instance,

16
00:00:40.182 --> 00:00:42.896
your communication was not in
the language of the audience.

17
00:00:42.896 --> 00:00:45.673
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz I hadn't got a clue what you were

18
00:00:45.673 --> 00:00:47.119
talking about there.

19

>> SpongeBob Squarepants,
the little fish who lives in a pineapple.

20
00:00:50.133 --> 00:00:51.900
>> You've got sponge, under the sea.

21
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:54.985
You've got kids.

22
00:00:54.985 --> 00:00:57.235
[LAUGH]
>> That's all I can say.

23
00:00:57.235 --> 00:01:02.153
Mine grew up a long time ago,
I think, apparently.

24
00:01:02.153 --> 00:01:02.996
So I've been told.

25
00:01:02.996 --> 00:01:04.486
[LAUGH]
>> I'd probably watch it even if

26
00:01:04.486 --> 00:01:04.990
I didn't have kids.

27
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:06.331
It's a good one.

28
00:01:06.331 --> 00:01:06.892
>> Dear.

29
00:01:06.892 --> 00:01:07.885
Okay, moving on.

30
00:01:07.885 --> 00:01:10.892
>> [LAUGH]
>> We are gonna talk about

31
00:01:10.892 --> 00:01:12.143
communication, yes.

32
00:01:12.143 --> 00:01:14.074
We're going to look at really,

33
00:01:14.074 --> 00:01:17.800
it's a follow-on from
organizational change management.

34
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:20.480
And we're going to look at the fact that

35
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:23.730
communication is key to
absolutely everything.

36
00:01:23.730 --> 00:01:26.950
It's about how we talk,
we're communicating all the time,

37
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:28.210
in everything that we do.

38
00:01:28.210 --> 00:01:31.850
In our body language,
in the words that we use,

39
00:01:31.850 --> 00:01:35.589
in the way that we talk,
in the tone of our voice.

40
00:01:35.589 --> 00:01:36.242
>> Yeah.

41
00:01:36.242 --> 00:01:39.199
>> [LAUGH] In our facial expressions.

42
00:01:39.199 --> 00:01:43.042
Absolutely everything that we do really
we're communicating absolutely all

43
00:01:43.042 --> 00:01:43.572
the time.

44
00:01:43.572 --> 00:01:48.964
So when we are gonna talk about
communication and it's role within IT.

45
00:01:48.964 --> 00:01:52.835
Because everything we do, as I've already
said, is a form of communication.

46
00:01:52.835 --> 00:01:57.223
In other words, our body language and
our facial expressions and

47
00:01:57.223 --> 00:02:00.914
just our attitude,
that's a form of communication.

48
00:02:00.914 --> 00:02:03.450
Everything that we write
is a form of communication.

49
00:02:03.450 --> 00:02:06.820
Every single telephone call
that we make and receive,

50
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:08.953
that's a form of communication.

51
00:02:08.953 --> 00:02:11.122
Everything that we text.

52
00:02:11.122 --> 00:02:14.420
It's something else that we've written,
that's a form of communication.

53
00:02:14.420 --> 00:02:18.375
So we have some basic communication
principles here within ITIL.

54
00:02:18.375 --> 00:02:22.158
But we have to remember,
as we make any major change,

55
00:02:22.158 --> 00:02:26.362
as we implement any new process,
as we update any process,

56
00:02:26.362 --> 00:02:29.979
as we implement any new
improvement opportunity,

57
00:02:29.979 --> 00:02:33.871
we have to remember these
communication principles.

58
00:02:33.871 --> 00:02:37.885
And we've got five communication
principles that are on the screen right in

59
00:02:37.885 --> 00:02:38.645
front of you.

60
00:02:38.645 --> 00:02:39.540
See, look at that.

61
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:42.025
That's a form of communication,
very effective.

62
00:02:42.025 --> 00:02:43.641
[LAUGH] It just happened.

63
00:02:43.641 --> 00:02:46.355
It appeared as if by magic.

64
00:02:46.355 --> 00:02:50.044
So we're gonna look at the fact that
communication is a 2-way process,

65
00:02:50.044 --> 00:02:54.029
that we are communicating all the time,
that timing and frequency matter, and

66
00:02:54.029 --> 00:02:56.545
that there is no single
method of communication.

67
00:02:56.545 --> 00:02:59.984
And of course the message is in the media.

68
00:02:59.984 --> 00:03:06.126
So, the first one here then,
communication is a 2-way process.

69
00:03:06.126 --> 00:03:09.280
Communication, as we've already said, it's
gotta be in the language of the audience.

70
00:03:09.280 --> 00:03:13.725
But you know what,
as the communicator in this instance,

71
00:03:13.725 --> 00:03:17.458
it's my job to make sure
that you understand me.

72
00:03:17.458 --> 00:03:19.245
And in the case of Cherokee,

73
00:03:19.245 --> 00:03:23.868
it's her job to make sure that I
understand her when she's talking to me.

74
00:03:23.868 --> 00:03:28.051
So talking to me about something
that I don't understand at all,

75
00:03:28.051 --> 00:03:31.330
not exactly effective in
terms of communication.

76
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:33.371
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

77
00:03:33.371 --> 00:03:36.503
>> It is my job, it's the communicator's

78
00:03:36.503 --> 00:03:41.303
responsibility to make sure
that the message is understood.

79
00:03:41.303 --> 00:03:46.087
It is not just good enough for
me put on the end of an email,

80
00:03:46.087 --> 00:03:52.202
did you get that, is that okay,
let me know if you've got any problems.

81
00:03:52.202 --> 00:03:55.853
Because that's not checking understanding.

82
00:03:55.853 --> 00:03:58.580
Let's just think about this,
just for a moment.

83
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:02.122
And I'm gonna start and
play with some language here,

84
00:04:02.122 --> 00:04:04.666
because I like playing with language.

85
00:04:04.666 --> 00:04:09.400
The word revise,
what does that word mean to you?

86
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:14.116
If I sent you an email, Cherokee,
and I told you to go away.

87
00:04:14.116 --> 00:04:16.253
And I'd sent you a set of course notes.

88
00:04:16.253 --> 00:04:20.276
And I told you to go away and
revise that set of course notes.

89
00:04:20.276 --> 00:04:21.454
What would you do?

90
00:04:21.454 --> 00:04:22.962
>> Update them.

91
00:04:22.962 --> 00:04:27.815
>> Right, wrong,
[LAUGH] cuz what I'd actually want

92
00:04:27.815 --> 00:04:31.636
you to do is I'd want you to study them.

93
00:04:31.636 --> 00:04:36.060
>> Yeah, I do remember you telling
me this before, the difference.

94
00:04:36.060 --> 00:04:38.788
>> There are two dictionary
definitions of the word revise.

95
00:04:38.788 --> 00:04:42.498
One means to study and
the other means to update.

96
00:04:42.498 --> 00:04:47.645
Of course, we have revision history for
instance, in our documentation.

97
00:04:47.645 --> 00:04:51.552
In the UK,
we use the word revise to mean study,

98
00:04:51.552 --> 00:04:55.970
because we use one dictionary definition.

99
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:59.714
Here in the US, we use a completely
different dictionary definition.

100
00:04:59.714 --> 00:05:01.220
Neither one of them are wrong.

101
00:05:01.220 --> 00:05:04.640
It's just that we use
them both differently.

102
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:08.637
So if I send you an email with
an attached presentation,

103
00:05:08.637 --> 00:05:12.560
and I said to you,
could you revise this for tomorrow?

104
00:05:12.560 --> 00:05:15.134
Then you would make changes.

105
00:05:15.134 --> 00:05:19.797
And what would actually happen, is I
could put at the bottom of that email,

106
00:05:19.797 --> 00:05:22.770
let me know if you understand,
or is that okay?

107
00:05:22.770 --> 00:05:26.677
And you would still come back to me and
say, yes, that's fine.

108
00:05:26.677 --> 00:05:29.131
But you would've taken one
interpretation away, and

109
00:05:29.131 --> 00:05:32.420
I would have meant something
completely different.

110
00:05:32.420 --> 00:05:36.840
So it's not just enough to write at
the bottom of an email, is that okay,

111
00:05:36.840 --> 00:05:39.967
because the interpretation
could still be wrong.

112
00:05:39.967 --> 00:05:42.994
>> Be like yeah, that's great,
I'll send them to you later and

113
00:05:42.994 --> 00:05:44.867
then they'll be like, wait, what?

114
00:05:44.867 --> 00:05:49.665
>> Exactly, so this is not just good
enough to make sure that you've

115
00:05:49.665 --> 00:05:53.869
read it and
that you've actually understood the words.

116
00:05:53.869 --> 00:05:57.150
I need to make sure that you've
understood the meaning behind the words.

117
00:05:57.150 --> 00:05:58.437
>> Get the proper context of writing.

118
00:05:58.437 --> 00:06:02.759
>> Right, and this is why we say that
the responsibility of communications it

119
00:06:02.759 --> 00:06:06.405
is in the hands of the person
that's doing the communicating.

120
00:06:06.405 --> 00:06:10.896
So it's my responsibility to talk to
you in a language that you understand.

121
00:06:10.896 --> 00:06:15.549
So it's my responsibility to make sure
that I use your words and your meaning.

122
00:06:15.549 --> 00:06:19.066
Now, we all know the difference
between petrol and gas for instance.

123
00:06:19.066 --> 00:06:23.714
That one's a fairly obvious one, but
that word revise is not fairly obvious.

124
00:06:23.714 --> 00:06:26.908
What about a simple little things
like a biscuit, for instance.

125
00:06:26.908 --> 00:06:29.005
What's a biscuit to you?

126
00:06:29.005 --> 00:06:31.728
>> A fluffy piece of southern goodness.

127
00:06:31.728 --> 00:06:35.591
>> Right, [LAUGH] looks more like a scone.

128
00:06:35.591 --> 00:06:36.925
That's all I'm saying.

129
00:06:36.925 --> 00:06:41.135
A biscuit to me is something that's
quite hard that I dunk in my tea.

130
00:06:41.135 --> 00:06:42.227
That's a biscuit.

131
00:06:42.227 --> 00:06:43.716
>> No, it's not.

132
00:06:43.716 --> 00:06:45.806
>> We've got differences that
we know about about, but

133
00:06:45.806 --> 00:06:47.950
then there are differences
that we don't know about.

134
00:06:47.950 --> 00:06:52.940
And so it's definitely,
it's in my responsibility to make sure

135
00:06:52.940 --> 00:06:57.121
that I communicate in
a language that you understand.

136
00:06:57.121 --> 00:07:00.972
And so you will notice me throughout
all of these ITIL classes,

137
00:07:00.972 --> 00:07:04.182
you will notice me use two
different types of words.

138
00:07:04.182 --> 00:07:06.010
And I'll always use maybe one word for

139
00:07:06.010 --> 00:07:09.507
one thing, and then I'll say something
completely different as well.

140
00:07:09.507 --> 00:07:13.597
Because I want to make sure, like I've
never called something a tickbox.

141
00:07:13.597 --> 00:07:18.658
I'll always say either a tick or a check,
because it depends on where in the world

142
00:07:18.658 --> 00:07:23.365
you are as to what you perceive to be
that little symbol that goes like that.

143
00:07:23.365 --> 00:07:27.150
Because to me it's a tick, but to you-
>> A tick is something I don't want.

144
00:07:27.150 --> 00:07:28.373
>> Right, okay.

145
00:07:28.373 --> 00:07:33.851
[LAUGH] So communication is a 2-way
process, and what that means is that we've

146
00:07:33.851 --> 00:07:39.100
both got to understand exactly what's
being meant by that communication.

147
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:45.363
Now, our next slide looks at
we're communicating all the time.

148
00:07:45.363 --> 00:07:46.483
And that's really simple.

149
00:07:46.483 --> 00:07:51.489
As I've already said, talk about body
language, talk about a facial expression

150
00:07:51.489 --> 00:07:56.437
and everything that we do, even silence,
is a form of communication as it says.

151
00:07:56.437 --> 00:07:57.033
>> You bet.

152
00:07:57.033 --> 00:07:59.406
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, but
I'm not talking to you.

153
00:07:59.406 --> 00:08:01.610
You better believe there's
something wrong, okay?

154
00:08:02.630 --> 00:08:03.980
And what I also want you to do is,

155
00:08:03.980 --> 00:08:07.120
I want you to take note of this
stakeholder communication plan.

156
00:08:07.120 --> 00:08:10.680
Now, that's something that we
looked at earlier on during

157
00:08:10.680 --> 00:08:12.730
our sessions in previous episodes.

158
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:16.890
And the stakeholder communication plan, as
I've already said, anything that's written

159
00:08:16.890 --> 00:08:22.200
in red, that means that it's in our ITIL
book, in our ITIL practitioner book.

160
00:08:22.200 --> 00:08:26.836
So we make use of the stakeholder
communication plan to

161
00:08:26.836 --> 00:08:29.568
help us formally communicate.

162
00:08:29.568 --> 00:08:32.951
And then let's look,
excuse me, let's look at this.

163
00:08:32.951 --> 00:08:36.289
Timing and frequency matter.

164
00:08:36.289 --> 00:08:38.537
Don't over or under communicate.

165
00:08:38.537 --> 00:08:42.977
Cherokee, have you ever had
an email that you've deleted before

166
00:08:42.977 --> 00:08:44.681
you've even opened it?

167
00:08:44.681 --> 00:08:46.102
>> Probably, every day.

168
00:08:46.102 --> 00:08:48.551
[LAUGH]
>> But all of them.

169
00:08:48.551 --> 00:08:52.989
[LAUGH] No, I've got to admit
that will probably delete.

170
00:08:52.989 --> 00:08:56.540
I have a special Email folder which
is where all my junk email goes.

171
00:08:56.540 --> 00:08:59.618
And I just go in and
I just delete it without even opening it.

172
00:08:59.618 --> 00:09:03.637
Because sometimes, you'll get two or
three emails a day from the same company.

173
00:09:03.637 --> 00:09:05.198
>> Right.

174
00:09:05.198 --> 00:09:09.600
>> Too frequent communication, people
just do not see the relevance in that.

175
00:09:09.600 --> 00:09:11.600
They do not see the importance in there.

176
00:09:11.600 --> 00:09:13.413
Infrequent communication, well,

177
00:09:13.413 --> 00:09:16.339
that actually suggests that
there is a lack of importance.

178
00:09:16.339 --> 00:09:22.140
And yet, again, people don't see the
relevance in that type of communication.

179
00:09:23.730 --> 00:09:27.320
Now, the second from the last
bullet point there, and

180
00:09:27.320 --> 00:09:29.580
I don't know if we can expand that slide.

181
00:09:29.580 --> 00:09:34.499
Yeah, that second from last bullet
point there about communicating

182
00:09:34.499 --> 00:09:37.483
at times of critical business activity.

183
00:09:37.483 --> 00:09:39.111
Yeah, don't do that.

184
00:09:39.111 --> 00:09:41.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> We don't want to communicate.

185
00:09:41.250 --> 00:09:44.286
If somebody's busy with something else,

186
00:09:44.286 --> 00:09:48.007
you can communicate
a critical business activity.

187
00:09:48.007 --> 00:09:49.883
But let's face it, at the end of the day,

188
00:09:49.883 --> 00:09:52.950
that communication is not gonna be
taken any notice of whatsoever.

189
00:09:54.170 --> 00:09:58.430
So that bullet point there, then, the one
that's just up from the bottom one there,

190
00:09:58.430 --> 00:10:01.700
the don't communicate at times
of critical business activity.

191
00:10:01.700 --> 00:10:05.260
Well, I mean, again, a lot of this,
as I've already said, is common sense, and

192
00:10:05.260 --> 00:10:07.960
this one goes without saying as well.

193
00:10:07.960 --> 00:10:11.823
If you're communicating to somebody at
a time when they're busy with something

194
00:10:11.823 --> 00:10:14.626
else, then they're not gonna
read your communication.

195
00:10:14.626 --> 00:10:17.659
So think about the timing.

196
00:10:17.659 --> 00:10:19.876
Don't communicate when
somebody's already busy.

197
00:10:19.876 --> 00:10:23.070
[LAUGH] Right, because, like I said,
they're not going to read it.

198
00:10:23.070 --> 00:10:23.980
Or they might read it and

199
00:10:23.980 --> 00:10:27.060
might not understand the severity
of your communication.

200
00:10:28.200 --> 00:10:32.200
And it's the same when somebody's
communicating at a time when you have got

201
00:10:32.200 --> 00:10:34.337
something critical going on yourself.

202
00:10:34.337 --> 00:10:36.440
You don't read it,
you don't take any notice of it.

203
00:10:36.440 --> 00:10:39.595
Or you might think to yourself,
I'll get back to that and

204
00:10:39.595 --> 00:10:43.300
not actually really understand
what the content of that email is.

205
00:10:43.300 --> 00:10:46.872
What about those times when you don't
pick up the telephone because you're in

206
00:10:46.872 --> 00:10:49.160
the middle of doing something else?

207
00:10:49.160 --> 00:10:50.590
That's a key point.

208
00:10:50.590 --> 00:10:54.321
Don't communicate when there's
something else going on, leave it.

209
00:10:54.321 --> 00:10:56.688
Communicate either before or
perhaps afterwards,

210
00:10:56.688 --> 00:10:59.570
when everything's had
a chance to settle down.

211
00:10:59.570 --> 00:11:02.710
And just remember that there's
no single way of communication.

212
00:11:02.710 --> 00:11:04.620
There's no method that's gonna work for
everybody.

213
00:11:04.620 --> 00:11:09.442
Some people will respond better to face
to face communications because you

214
00:11:09.442 --> 00:11:10.983
can see body language.

215
00:11:10.983 --> 00:11:14.394
Other people will respond
better to telephone calls.

216
00:11:14.394 --> 00:11:17.457
Some people respond better to emails.

217
00:11:17.457 --> 00:11:21.650
Use a mix of communication methods, yeah?

218
00:11:21.650 --> 00:11:23.952
Don't just send an email.

219
00:11:23.952 --> 00:11:25.814
Confirm it via a telephone call.

220
00:11:25.814 --> 00:11:27.425
Don't just make a telephone call.

221
00:11:27.425 --> 00:11:29.736
Confirm it via an email.

222
00:11:29.736 --> 00:11:33.590
What about the medium that
we're using right now, video?

223
00:11:33.590 --> 00:11:37.758
Think about this, what I will do is,

224
00:11:37.758 --> 00:11:42.874
we will communicate now,
over a TV episode.

225
00:11:42.874 --> 00:11:45.400
And then,
I give you a set of exercises to do.

226
00:11:45.400 --> 00:11:49.846
And I'll say to you, okay, do these
exercises because I need to know that

227
00:11:49.846 --> 00:11:53.170
you've understood what we've talked about.

228
00:11:53.170 --> 00:11:56.669
And then, I'll give you
another form of communication.

229
00:11:56.669 --> 00:11:59.386
Because I'll say to you,
if you've got any questions,

230
00:11:59.386 --> 00:12:03.075
if you didn't quite understand anything,
then come back to us on the forum.

231
00:12:03.075 --> 00:12:05.711
Remember, that 2-way process,
come back to me.

232
00:12:05.711 --> 00:12:09.717
Come back to me on the forum, and I will
answer any questions that you may have.

233
00:12:09.717 --> 00:12:13.690
And so at that point in time,
I've used three methods of communication.

234
00:12:13.690 --> 00:12:18.970
I've communicated with you face to face,
now, over video.

235
00:12:18.970 --> 00:12:22.700
Then I've communicated with you through
the exercises because I have given you

236
00:12:22.700 --> 00:12:24.170
something to think about.

237
00:12:24.170 --> 00:12:28.760
And then I'm asking you to communicate
back to me via chat, for instance, or

238
00:12:28.760 --> 00:12:33.550
over whatever misunderstandings
that you might have, or

239
00:12:33.550 --> 00:12:36.200
whatever confusions that you may have.

240
00:12:36.200 --> 00:12:38.890
So we use a mix of communication methods.

241
00:12:38.890 --> 00:12:43.135
But we have to remember that not
everything works for every single person.

242
00:12:43.135 --> 00:12:46.549
And you have to use the right mix
in order to be able to get through

243
00:12:46.549 --> 00:12:48.265
to absolutely everybody.

244
00:12:48.265 --> 00:12:51.840
And, of course, think about the severity
of your communication as well.

245
00:12:53.140 --> 00:12:56.031
Okay, the method has got to be
appropriate to the scale and

246
00:12:56.031 --> 00:12:58.273
to the impact of that
communication as well.

247
00:12:58.273 --> 00:13:02.195
You don't tell somebody that
they've been laid off via a text.

248
00:13:02.195 --> 00:13:04.284
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

249
00:13:04.284 --> 00:13:04.910
>> I hope not, yeah.

250
00:13:04.910 --> 00:13:10.809
>> Yeah, right, I mean, it's kind of
the one that I've used before in the past.

251
00:13:10.809 --> 00:13:13.094
No, you can't dump anybody via text.

252
00:13:13.094 --> 00:13:14.955
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or

253
00:13:14.955 --> 00:13:17.530
just simply unfriend them on Facebook,
right?

254
00:13:17.530 --> 00:13:18.570
Isn't that the way it goes?

255
00:13:18.570 --> 00:13:19.851
>> Yeah.

256
00:13:19.851 --> 00:13:21.644
>> You can't do that, okay.

257
00:13:21.644 --> 00:13:24.902
You have to think about the appropriate
method of communication.

258
00:13:24.902 --> 00:13:29.049
And it has to be relevant to the scale and
to the impact of any improvement

259
00:13:29.049 --> 00:13:32.350
initiative that you're
trying to undertake.

260
00:13:32.350 --> 00:13:37.235
You don't need to send a huge big
email when only two words will do.

261
00:13:37.235 --> 00:13:41.514
But you don't want to put anything severe,
such as restructuring,

262
00:13:41.514 --> 00:13:43.080
in a text either, okay?

263
00:13:43.080 --> 00:13:44.668
It has to be appropriate.

264
00:13:44.668 --> 00:13:47.587
And just remember that written
communication can be misinterpreted.

265
00:13:47.587 --> 00:13:48.929
We've already spoken about this.

266
00:13:48.929 --> 00:13:50.943
Think of that word revise, okay?

267
00:13:50.943 --> 00:13:53.830
So remember that communication
is a 2-way process.

268
00:13:55.500 --> 00:13:58.710
What you have to do is we have to
create what we call a stakeholder

269
00:13:58.710 --> 00:14:00.580
communication plan.

270
00:14:00.580 --> 00:14:03.730
And we've already seen that in
two of our previous slides.

271
00:14:03.730 --> 00:14:05.210
It's been written in red.

272
00:14:05.210 --> 00:14:06.790
That means that if it's written in red,

273
00:14:06.790 --> 00:14:10.060
it's in our toolkit within
our ITIL practitioner book.

274
00:14:11.090 --> 00:14:15.057
And we have to ensure that every
single stakeholder is covered so

275
00:14:15.057 --> 00:14:17.705
that we identify all of our stakeholders.

276
00:14:17.705 --> 00:14:21.345
And we should do that right at the very
beginning of any improvement initiative

277
00:14:21.345 --> 00:14:24.140
when we're planning out that project.

278
00:14:24.140 --> 00:14:28.560
And we need to ensure that once we've
got all the stakeholders written down,

279
00:14:28.560 --> 00:14:34.190
that we're able to identify what
communication methods are relevant for

280
00:14:34.190 --> 00:14:36.560
those particular stakeholders.

281
00:14:36.560 --> 00:14:40.580
And you've got to answer the question,
what's in it for me?

282
00:14:40.580 --> 00:14:43.700
Remember all of your communication
principles, such as timing and

283
00:14:43.700 --> 00:14:45.630
frequency matter.

284
00:14:45.630 --> 00:14:51.985
Don't communicate by way of a meeting
twice a week when you're communicating to,

285
00:14:51.985 --> 00:14:57.909
say, an external third party, a supplier,
or maybe an external customer.

286
00:14:57.909 --> 00:15:01.740
Because, perhaps they won't want
to have a meeting twice a week.

287
00:15:01.740 --> 00:15:03.638
Perhaps they don't have time.

288
00:15:03.638 --> 00:15:07.936
So think about your communication and
plan your communication.

289
00:15:07.936 --> 00:15:10.550
And then make sure you
have got a method for

290
00:15:10.550 --> 00:15:13.170
feedback of that communication as well.

291
00:15:14.260 --> 00:15:18.370
Different types of communication
that we have are all listed here.

292
00:15:18.370 --> 00:15:24.080
This is not necessarily a list of
all of the types of communication.

293
00:15:24.080 --> 00:15:27.050
You'll decide how best to
communicate with your team.

294
00:15:28.260 --> 00:15:34.420
I've seen sort of town hall meetings, etc,
that are done via a video communication

295
00:15:34.420 --> 00:15:40.438
method that are sort of beamed around the
world, as it were, all at the same time.

296
00:15:40.438 --> 00:15:42.334
What about simulation games?

297
00:15:42.334 --> 00:15:47.666
That's something that's now moving into
our common workplace environment where

298
00:15:47.666 --> 00:15:52.704
we actually perform simulation or
the gamification of some training as well.

299
00:15:52.704 --> 00:15:55.928
>> We even integrate that here at
ITProTV with badges and stuff.

300
00:15:55.928 --> 00:15:59.998
>> Right, yeah, yeah, this is something
that we would encourage is being

301
00:15:59.998 --> 00:16:02.209
interactive with our communication.

302
00:16:02.209 --> 00:16:06.408
Because when we can encourage that
interactiveness, then that means that we

303
00:16:06.408 --> 00:16:10.420
are able to identify whether
a message has been understood or not.

304
00:16:10.420 --> 00:16:14.824
And I know that we'll give you exercises
to do with your ITIL training prior to

305
00:16:14.824 --> 00:16:17.279
your certification, prior to your exam.

306
00:16:17.279 --> 00:16:21.418
But, nevertheless,
it's still not fully interactive.

307
00:16:21.418 --> 00:16:26.269
Because we're not fully interacting live,
right now, with you to identify

308
00:16:26.269 --> 00:16:30.460
whether you've understood or
whether you haven't understood.

309
00:16:31.540 --> 00:16:35.280
So that's why we use those exercises
to come back to us at a later date.

310
00:16:35.280 --> 00:16:39.594
And then we can feedback to you as to
whether you're on the right track, or

311
00:16:39.594 --> 00:16:44.761
maybe whether you kinda missed the point
on something, cuz it's perfectly feasible.

312
00:16:44.761 --> 00:16:48.336
Think about how you're gonna communicate,
and think about at

313
00:16:48.336 --> 00:16:53.510
what stage during your improvement
initiative you're going to communicate.

314
00:16:53.510 --> 00:16:59.360
So here we have an example, to get from
our current state to our predicted state,

315
00:16:59.360 --> 00:17:01.930
look at what we have to communicate and
when.

316
00:17:01.930 --> 00:17:06.005
First thing that we've got to do,
we already know, is identify the vision.

317
00:17:06.005 --> 00:17:08.930
And then,
we communicate at various stages,

318
00:17:08.930 --> 00:17:12.838
such as when we've got our
leadership team and our sponsors.

319
00:17:12.838 --> 00:17:17.221
Then we'll communicate when we
are establishing who our contributing

320
00:17:17.221 --> 00:17:18.470
groups are.

321
00:17:18.470 --> 00:17:21.120
In other words,
can you get involved with this?

322
00:17:21.120 --> 00:17:23.160
We'd really like you to.

323
00:17:23.160 --> 00:17:27.370
We'll communicate targets, and
then once we've implemented

324
00:17:27.370 --> 00:17:31.100
our improvement initiative,
then we'll communicate that as well.

325
00:17:32.400 --> 00:17:37.100
All of these are just
examples of timings for

326
00:17:37.100 --> 00:17:40.420
communication, but there's no right or
wrong to communication at all.

327
00:17:41.690 --> 00:17:45.940
We can communicate whenever we need to and
as frequently as we need to.

328
00:17:45.940 --> 00:17:48.250
But just remember that we
don't over communicate.

329
00:17:49.470 --> 00:17:55.170
So now then, well, we have come to
the end of our course materials for

330
00:17:55.170 --> 00:17:57.170
our ITIL practitioner show.

331
00:17:58.200 --> 00:18:02.271
And at this point in time, this is
when I ask you to review everything,

332
00:18:02.271 --> 00:18:06.756
all the principles that we have learned
throughout our previous episodes and

333
00:18:06.756 --> 00:18:10.770
to undertake the exercises that
are in your downloadable material.

334
00:18:10.770 --> 00:18:15.545
Now, as I already mentioned,
right in the very first episode of

335
00:18:15.545 --> 00:18:20.412
ITIL practitioner, the ITIL
practitioner course itself is made

336
00:18:20.412 --> 00:18:25.454
up of a minimum of 50% exercises
that you will perform yourself,

337
00:18:25.454 --> 00:18:31.760
to ensure that you've understood
the principles that we've discussed.

338
00:18:31.760 --> 00:18:35.542
>> So we've reached the end of our
shows and our episodes right now.

339
00:18:35.542 --> 00:18:40.395
But now, you've got about 10-12 hours
worth of exercises that you will

340
00:18:40.395 --> 00:18:45.270
need to undertake in order to ensure
understanding of all of the principles.

341
00:18:45.270 --> 00:18:48.830
Now, that doesn't include the 2 hours and

342
00:18:48.830 --> 00:18:53.030
15 minutes worth of sample paper
that you also have to undertake.

343
00:18:53.030 --> 00:18:58.130
In subsequent episodes, we're going to
look a little bit further at the exercises

344
00:18:58.130 --> 00:19:02.970
themselves and what I'm expecting
from you in those exercises.

345
00:19:02.970 --> 00:19:07.694
And we'll also be doing a review session,
or a few episodes, really,

346
00:19:07.694 --> 00:19:12.287
of review sessions, on the ITIL
practitioner tests, themselves.

347
00:19:12.287 --> 00:19:17.225
So at this point in time,
this is where I leave it up to you.

348
00:19:17.225 --> 00:19:22.215
And I'll see you in some subsequent
episodes to review what you

349
00:19:22.215 --> 00:19:27.027
have covered in your exercises
as also in your sample paper.

350
00:19:27.027 --> 00:19:29.824
>> All right, Jo, so it's looks like
we've got some homework to do here.

351
00:19:29.824 --> 00:19:31.009
But definitely come back,

352
00:19:31.009 --> 00:19:33.542
because we do have some more
information headed your way.

353
00:19:33.542 --> 00:19:35.648
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

354
00:19:35.648 --> 00:19:37.291
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

355
00:19:37.291 --> 00:19:38.202
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

356
00:19:38.202 --> 00:19:40.964
>> See you next time, here at ITProTV.

357
00:19:40.964 --> 00:19:47.062

358
00:19:47.062 --> 00:19:49.913
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.
